title: tory-candidate-vying-scotlands-first-black-msp-hopes-inspire-others
story: Ade Aibinu, who is standing in Glasgow Anniesland as well as on the Glasgow list, said: "People need to be able to see what they want to become."He told The Herald: "Its much easier to aspire to be a parliamentarianyou can see someone who is a parliamentarian and who looks and sounds like yourself."Mr Aibinu has been a councillor in Glasgow since , where he represents the Victoria Park ward.Originally from Nigeria, he moved to northern England in  and later to Glasgow for university. He now lectures at South Lanarkshire College.The Conservatives came third in Glasgow Anniesland in , while Mr Aibinus placing on the partys Glasgow list means he could face an uphill battle to secure a seat in Holyrood.But the -year-old said: "I want to get into the Scottish Parliament, but the key thing for me about leadership is its not just about getting into parliament."He added: "My ability to inspire the next generation for me is much more important than even getting into the Scottish Parliament."Because I could get into the Scottish Parliament, and not encourage anyone to get involved in politics. I think thats a failure of leadership."Evenby standing, Im encouraging people to stand for the Conservative Party, to be bold, I think thats a huge achievement in itself."The Scottish Parliament has faced criticism over its lack of ersity.Since , there have only been four MSPs from black, Asian and minority ethniccommunities. All have been men of Scots-Pakistani heritage.SNP Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf previously said this record of "no black MSP ever, no female BAME MSP ever" was "frankly a failure of all of us, regardless of party".The SNP has put BAME or disabled candidates top in its eight regional lists.The partys hopefuls include Graham Campbell, Glasgows first African Caribbean councillor, who is standing in Lothian.Mr Aibinu said Scotland had a "dferent pattern of migration compared to what we have down south in, for example, places like London".But he said it is becoming more erse, adding: "With that change there should come more representation in the Scottish Parliament."So I think what we have right now, Im actually quite encouraged that we have more candidates coming forward from specically a black background wanting to stand for the Scottish Parliament, and the Conservative Party is right at the forefront of this."He continued: "We now have a much larger pool of people in Scotland and in Glasgow specically, which is perhaps the most erse of the cities in Scotland."So Im hoping maybe at the next Westminster general election, wed have people from black backgrounds standing as well."However, he said representation is "not just about having elected members in parliament".He added: "Its also about parliament being open to communities."Mr Aibinu said there is "work to be done" but he is "encouraged by the current trajectory".He said: "From a policy perspective, mentorship is something we should encourage."The Tory hopeful said he had experienced racism in the past.He added: "I dont let it stop me. Ive got my own personal aspiration, Ive got a goal and a target, which is to ensure that my communities are well represented at local level, and well see what the Scottish electorate decide on May ."Mr Aibinu said his partys main message is to "end ision, rebuild Scotland and say No to a isive referendum".He also criticised the SNPs domestic record, including on education.

title: election-2021-pledge-scrap-p1-tests
story: The party said Scottish National Standardised Assessments , which are given to pupils in P, P, P and S, were causing unnecessary anxiety without providing a clear educational benefit.It also wants to reintroduce a previously used study, the Scottish Survey of Literacy and Numeracy , to monitor progress in learning.SNSAs are taken online and were introduced amid concern over sliding international performance scores in areas such as maths and science.:Parents slam test plan for Ps after schools reopenThere is no pass or fail and children do not have to revise or prepare for them. Proposals to scrap the tests come after ministers said earlier this year that they would remain available for teachers to deliver following disruption caused by Covid-related school closures.Ross Greer, education spokesperson for the Scottish Greens, said the decision to ldquoimpose standardised assessments on pupils as young as four was ldquoa mistake.He added: ldquoSNSAs create a pressure on teachers to narrow the curriculum and focus on satisfying test scores, rather than equipping young people with the skills and knowledge they need to succeed.ldquoThe Greens will scrap these tests at the first opportunity.Mr Greer said the SSLN provided important national data on attainment levels by sampling schools in a non-intrusive manner.Ross Greer said his party would axe the tests at the first opportunity.ldquoScotlandrsquos teachers meet some of the highest professional standards in the world, he added.ldquoWe should put our trust in them to deliver what their pupils need, rather than obsessively gather data which has little practical use.ldquoThe SSLN survey did exactly that, before the Government scrapped it. It gathered useful data from a representative sample of pupils while avoiding the pressures which come from testing every pupil and then judging their teachers and schools based on the results.Campaigners have welcomed the plans.Sue Palmer of Upstart Scotland, which wants to introduce a kindergarten stage for children aged -, said she hoped other political parties would announce similar proposals.:MSPs bid to raise school starting age to ldquoThere is a huge amount of evidence that four and five-year-olds should not be subjected to national standardised assessment of specic literacy and numeracy skills, she added.ldquoIt would, however, be very helpful to assess this age grouprsquos overall physical, social, emotional and cognitive development, as happens in Canada and Australia, using a well-researched assessment tool called the Early Development Instrument.ldquoThe EDI was successfully trialled in East Lothian in  but, despite excellent peer reviews, was not considered by the Scottish Government at the time, perhaps because they already had plans for the SNSA.ldquoFor the sake of Scotlandrsquos children ndash and, indeed, our countryrsquos future ndash we should like to see the EDI substituted for the P SNSA.

title: scottish-rise-cycling-needs-work-maintained
story: Were in the park for exercise, his dad and I walking and the little guy on his bike. Off he careens, into the distance, until hes just a speck, that invisible elastic between parent and child stretching but never breaking.Seeing that level of confidence and enjoyment is wonderful to watch. You only hope it continues, becomes a le long pleasure.In the first few months of the pandemic, among all the hardships and relentless grim news, it really was wonderful to see such an increase in people out on bikes.We were inching into the summer months and, with just one hour allowed outdoors, many people chose to use that time cycling.The parks were full of people exploring but vastly reduced traffic and quiet roads made cycling around the city a relaxed experience, rather than one spent hyper vigilant, watching for trouble, and so many more new cyclists were taking advantage of the situation.Those numbers have kept increasing and the latest figures, this week, show that cycling is up by % in Scotland.While thats good news, it also makes a lot of sense. The roads are still quieter than pre-pandemic, there is still a hesitancy to use public transport, and were so limited in our leisure options that people are turning to outdoor pursuits for exercise and socialising.There has also been a huge push from local authorities during the lockdown to create more space for people walking and cycling and to make the roads more amenable to non-vehicular traffic.The issue, as we move forward through and out of the pandemic, is going to be about how we keep encouraging people on to their bikes and give them the confidence to feel free in the saddle.Even with the improvements of the past  months, barriers still exist, particularly for women cyclists.In Scotland, more than three times as many men than women commute to work by bike.When asked, women speak about concerns over safety. They are worried about the harassment they face while out on their bikes. Id love to tell you that cat calls and aggression are an unfounded fear, but I would be lying.Often women are the ones doing the school run, which is not impossible by bike but understandably has logistical concerns that can be off putting.Research from Sustrans showed that, as well as fitness levels and safety, womens concerns were linked to their appearance. If that seems like vanity, its not. Women are judged on how they look and it can be a faff to commute by bike then look smart for the office.It involves forward planning, carrying clothes back and forth, arriving at work early to change and sort hair and make up in toilets, and etc. A tip: waterproof trousers will change your le.There is nothing worse than spending the morning on an office chair with a soggy bottom.I completely understand the hesitancy to start cycling and the fear of being on the road. It makes me laugh to look back at how gradually I took my bike out. I started off literally cycling to the end of my street and back. Then I was brave enough to make it to the park for a cycle round and home again.Eventually a colleague, who lives nearby, offered to accompany me on the commute to the office. He was big and bold and I hidbehind him the whole way there and all the way back again.There are lots of ways of getting support with confidence building though. In Glasgow, Bike For Good is a brilliant social enterprise doing great work helping people new to cycling and supporting cyclists to maintain their bikes.Bike For Good acknowledges that cycling can have particular challenges for women and non-binary people and that bike maintenance can be a male-dominated area so they have specic sessions catered for people who dont identy as men. Theres also a new buddy scheme being set up.In cities theresissues with cycle storage for those in flats and tenements but this is slowly being addressed with the introduction of on-street secure cycleparking.Despite the improvements over the past year, its good to get out with a more confident buddy as some of Glasgows cycle routes are bonkers and can be off-putting to a novice. You can find yourself having to bump down kerbs to keep on the route being erted away from well lit and visible paths on to glass-strewn, cobbled back lanes or one moment be dutully following painted routes and the next moment come up against metal railings with nowhere to go.But when you find yourself sailing along a well-constructed, properly thought out, segregated cycle route... theres nothing like it. Gliding along, away from the traffic, fresh air in your face.Yes, sometimes dirt spraying from the road onto your cheeks yes, sometimes rain suddenly bursting unexpectedly from a clear sky yes, sometimes wind in your face that makes your thighs ache from the effort of pedalling.Cycling is not always joyous but there is always a little bit of joy about it.One of the major barriers, though, and the most dficult to tackle, is the ingrained lack of respect for cyclists and cycling. Not only from drivers but from those who are creating our cycle lanes.This morning, on a short, two-mile journey from Glasgow Sherf Court to the South Side, I had to navigate around five cars parked in cycle lanes and then three workmens vans stopped on the South City Way segregated cycle route. Drivers are more often than not parked on the South City Way.Theyll argue that they cant block the road but thats part of the problem with how we perceive cycling infrastructure - as though it is an added extra, a luxury, rather than fundamental. The car is still king and its routes to be as protected as a royal parade.As the cycle routes around the south side of the city are developed there have been a lot of roadworks. Every effort is made to keep carriageways open for cars but the bike lanes are closed and replaced with the dreaded Cyclists Dismount signs.I look forward to the day that changes are needed to facilitate roadworks and drivers are told to Park Here and walk the rest of the way. Thats obviously an imperfect comparison but it almost literally grinds my gears that these road changes dont take into account the fact cyclists are also commuters with somewhere to be.The ersions that are put in place for cyclists can sometimes be mind-bendingly confusing. Theres one at Buchanan Wharf, as you come off the Squiggly Bridge, that has painted arrows for cyclists that,you follow them, take you right into the path of oncoming foot traffic with nowhere  to go.I do, though, see improvements being made. The way to encourage more people to cycle is fairly simple - make cities and town centres less attractive to cars so other activities and means of transport naturally fill those spaces.Its an exciting time for cyclists and its a good time to be supporting people to take up cycling. There are hurdles but hard work going on to overcome them.Just imagine - city spaces where you can be free to fly as confidently as a four-year-old whos learned the pleasure of two wheels.

title: scottish-independence-nicola-sturgeon-gives-firm-no-working-alex-salmond
story: The First Minister insistedher focusis on fighting the upcoming election in a bid to win as many seatsfor the SNP as possible.However, although she said they were "hypothetical questions", she did not rule out the prospect of working with the Greens,who also favour Scottish independence ndasha coalition is needed.Scottish Green Party co-leader Lorna Slater previously spoke out about the prospect of a coalition between the two parties, saying the Greens ldquowant to be in government in this country.Ms Sturgeon, speaking to the Scottish Parliamentary Journalistsrsquo Association, refused to rule out a future coalition.She said: ldquoI am concentrating on fighting this election and winning as many seats as possible for the SNP. These are hypothetical questions until after the elections are over.But she added: ldquoWe have worked with the greens in Budget negotiations for the duration of the Parliament that has just passed, so I know we can work with the Greens on that kind of basis.However, the SNP leader said there have been "no discussions between the SNP and the Greens about anything more formal than that" and insists it remains a "hypothetical issue."Nevertheless, Ms Sturgeon has firmly ruled out working with Alex Salmonds Alba Party- responding witha straight ldquoNo.:Greens adamant unstoppable mandate for indyref will not be ignoredShe was clear: ldquoI am ruling out having any kind of arrangement with Alex Salmond or with Alba.With some opinion polls suggesting Mr Salmondrsquos new party may not win any seats on May ,Ms Sturgeon added this may not be ldquosomething I am going to have to contend with, though she stressed that ldquothese polls might change, and the margins are all very fine.Her comments came as she insisted the forthcoming Scottish Parliament elections were the most important Scotland has faced since Holyrood was established back in .She stated: ldquoGiven the times we are living through, given the seriousness of the challenges we face and given the choice for Scotland about our future, it is probably not an exaggeration to say this is the most important election certainly since devolution, and perhaps even longer than that.Ms Sturgeon insisted: ldquoIn the short term it really matters that we have strong, steady and experienced leadership as a country over the next few months.ldquoWe are still in a pandemic and the threat of Covid has abatedhellip but the threat has not gone ahead and the decisions that are taken over the next weeks and months, certainly into the summer, will be really important in determining how safely and quickly we get through the remaining phase of the pandemic.She also said that the policy programme brought in by the next Scottish Government would be key in the countryrsquos recovery from Covid-.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe iding lineis between those like the SNP who want to give the people a choice when the time is right and the unionist parties who never want Scotland to have that choice, who want Boris Johnson to hold the whip hand and for big decisions about our future to continue to lie in Westminster.:Nicola Sturgeon attacks Alex Salmond for going easy on murderous RussiaThe SNP leader continued: ldquoRecovery is rightly the focus of much of this election but what we recover to, and the kind of country we become out of that recovery depends to a large extent on who is taking those decisions and fundamentally where power lies.ldquoThat is why after the crisis, offering that choice to the people of Scotland is a key part of what we are putting forward in this election.

title: nicola-sturgeon-alex-salmonds-feud-escalates-independence-plans
story: The First Minister said that, although she wanted Indyref before the end of , the timing would depend on the situation with Covid, and it could be later in the five-year parliament.She also said that evena referendum was held on her preferred timetable, independence itself would not be until , by when much of the recovery could be over.Just last month, Ms Sturgeon told her party: ldquoIndependence is not a distraction from recovery. It is essential to secure a recovery that is made here in Scotland.Her comments drew a furious response from Alex Salmond, who wants independence talks to start in the first week after the election,who said Yes independence supporters would be ldquotaken aback by the apparent lack of urgency.:Nicola Sturgeon attacks Alex Salmond for going easy on murderous RussiaOpposition parties accused the current and previous first ministers of wasting their time and energy on fighting each other instead of focusing on the nationrsquos priorities.It followed Ms Sturgeon speaking to the media in an online QA which laid bare the extent of her rt with her predecessor and her disdain for his new list-only Alba Party.She rubbished Mr Salmondrsquos plan to deliver an lsquosupermajorityrsquo for independence at Holyrood through Alba, calling it ldquodaft rhetoric, and said she would refuse to pick up the phone to himhe was elected as an MSP in May and asked to work with her.She also accused Mr Salmond and Alba of misleading their own supporters by ldquotrying to pretend there is a shortcut to independence, rather than ldquohard work.His ideas for breaking up the UK without a second referendum also ran the risk of putting people off independence, she said.The SNP leader said people could either vote for ldquoserious leadership.. or folk who want to offer deceptively simplistic soundbites to actually quite complex challenges.Recent polls suggest the SNP is on the brink of winning its second outright majority at Holyrood, but support for Alba could jeopardise that without adding any more Yes MSPs.Boris Johnson has already refused to grant Indyref on the basis that the No vote of  should stand for a generation.Ms Sturgeon said it would be ldquoabsurd for him to do so in the face of another pro-independence majority at Holyrood, and said she understood Whitehall was already working on how it could dictate the question and franchise for another vote.:High-profile Albacandidate Tasmina Ahmed-Sheikh facing legal tribunal hearingShe said: ldquoFirstly can we knock on the head of this idea for some requirement for a supermajority. There is no requirement for a supermajority for the Scottish Parliament to back a referendum. What is needed is a simple majority of MSPs who back that."The party who has put forward the idea of supermajority hasnrsquot even been willing to define what that is, so letrsquos not get into the position of suggesting there is some greater hurdle for the Scottish Parliament to pass to have an independence referendum than there actually is."People who actually want to see a referendum and who believe in independence should be very cautious about any daft rhetoric of that nature.She said criticism from Alba supporters that she had been too slow in pursuing independence was ldquononsense, but added a note of caution given the pandemic.She said: ldquoMy preference would be to have the referendum and offer the choice to the people of Scotland within the first half of the parliament, which is a period that runs until the end of ."If in terms of whether that can definitely happen andso where within that timespan a referendum would actually happen depends on the situation with Covid."Right now we are still in the teeth of an acute phase of a pandemic, people are still living under very serious restrictions and as long as that continues, not least because people wouldnt be able to campaign properly."We are finding the restrictions of this campaign dficult enough, so for a whole host of reasons we need to get out of the crisis of Covid and then put that choice to the people of Scotland."So my preference is within the first half of the parliament but of course the demands and realities of Covid have to be what guides that decision.":Health Secretary Jeane Freeman admits moving patients into care homes was Covid mistakeMr Salmond has said thatthe PM refuses to grant Indyref again, other tactics such as street demos, international pressure and legal actions could be used to get independence instead.Ms Sturgeon said she understood her supporters impatience, but it would only happen ldquowhen a majority of the people of Scotland want that and vote for that in a legitimate process.She said: ldquoI have spent a lot of time over the past few years building amongst our European colleagues understanding and awareness and acceptance on the concept of independence. So itrsquos not about saying that none of these things have a part to play in a democracy.ldquoBut none of them are a substitute or an alternative to getting a majority of people to vote for independence in a legal, legitimate process.ldquoAnd I just thinkyou try to pretend they are you do two things in my view ndash neither of which are helpful."Firstly, you kind of mislead the supporters of independence who desperately want it because you are trying to pretend that there is a shortcut, which therersquos not.ldquoAnd secondly, and perhaps this is even more of a concern, you run the risk of instead of persuaded the so-far unpersuaded but open-minded towards you ndash you run the risk of pushing them away."Because, effectively what you are saying is it doesnrsquot matter winning a majority in a legal process, you just want to jump over that and bulldoze your way to independence."I donrsquot think what has been put forward by the Alba Party so far is credible."It doesnrsquot even pass the first test of credibility.:Tom Gordon -Something doesnt smell right about the Alba PartyAsked about working with her predecessor in the next parliament, she ruled out ldquoany kind of arrangement with Alex Salmond or with Alba.Askedshe would take a call from himhe wanted to discuss independence tactics after the election, she said: "I have a feeling that Alex wont be keen to pick up the phone to me any time soon."Pressed whether she would call him about independencethe parliamentary arithmetic demanded it, she said: "No."Responding, Mr Salmond said: "Independence supporters who are already underwhelmed at the lack of progress towards Independence over the last five years, despite there being a majority in the Parliament in favour of it, will be taken aback at the apparent lack of urgency towards Independence in the next Parliament.ldquoAs Scotland recovers from Covid we will need the full powers of Independence to renew our economy and society, which is why the drive to independence should be a priority, not something to be delayed.ldquoThat is exactly why we need an independence supermajority in the Scottish Parliament.Scottish Liberal Democrat campaign chair Alistair Carmichael said: ldquoSalmond and Sturgeon are once again focusing their energies on bickering with one another about independence, instead of talking about issues that really matter like education and mental health. Itrsquos sad to see two First Ministers completely ignoring reality and the needs of the Scottish people only to push forward their referendum.ldquoWe need to put recovery first now and Scotland needs a government which will put the needs of its people before childish feuds and constitutional conniving."Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said: ldquoThis is yet more confirmation from Nicola Sturgeon thatthe SNP win a majority, they will hold another isive independence referendum, regardless of what the UK Government says.ldquoScottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said: ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos blind spot on the constitution is on show yet again. The pandemic doesnrsquot end when the public health crisis does - our recovery should be the only priority in the next parliament.

title: greta-thunberg-wont-attend-glasgow-summit-cop26-should-postponed
story: The -year-old climate activist believes the COP summit should be postponed, with the focus instead on the global rollout of the coronavirus vaccination.World leaders are expected to attend the summit which has been described as the most signicant international meeting on climate change since the Paris Agreement in .It is being held at the Scottish Event Campusfrom November - and a call for volunteers to support staging the event has attracted , applicants ndash more than  times the roughly , places available.:UK Government denies claims Glasgow climate change summit COP could be postponedTaking to Twitter to explain her reasoning, Ms Thunberg said she would want everyone to have a chance to take part on equal terms.She explained:"Of course I would love to attend the Glasgow #COP, but not unless everyone can take part on the same terms."Right now many countries are vaccinating healthy young people, often at the expense of risk groups and front line workers ."Inequality and climate injustice is already the heart of the climate crisis. If people canrsquot be vaccinated and travel to be represented equally thatrsquos undemocratic and would worsen the problem. Vaccine nationalism wonrsquot solve the pandemic. Global problems need global solutions."She added: "Butcurrent trends continue and the #cop has to be delayed that doesnrsquot mean we have to delay the urgent action required. We donrsquot have to wait for conferences nor anyone or anything  to dramatically start reducing our emissions. Solidarity and action can start today."And a digital solution is of course far from optimal. High speed internet connection and access to computers is extremely unequal in the world. In that case we would lack representation from those whose voices need to be heard the most when it comes to the climate crisis."Elsewhere, MsThunberg also said the only way forward in the fight against climate change is to ldquotreat the crisis like a crisis.The Swedish climate and environmental activist was speaking ahead of the airing of BBC series Greta Thunberg: A Year To Change The World, which follows her journey during a year off school in  as she explores the science of global warming and challenges world leaders to take action.Over three episodes, the -year-old witnesses first-hand the consequences of climate change and also meets climate scientists and experts, among them naturalist and broadcaster Sir David Attenborough.On Monday   pm BST episode  of ldquoA Year To Change The World will air on @BBCOne .Itrsquos a documentary series in  parts which followed me during my year off school and explores the science behind the climate crisis. @bbcstudios pic kamworkkCmdash Greta ThunbergApril , Thunberg told the PA news agency: ldquoI would like to see us starting to treat the crisis like a crisis, because thatrsquos the only way forward.ldquoWe canrsquot say lsquoI would want them to do this, I would want them to shut down this, and I would want them to start this, and so onrsquo because, as long as thatrsquos not coming from the people, as long as people are not demanding it, itrsquos undemocratic, and democracy is the most powerful tool that we have.ldquoItrsquos the most precious thing that we have, which we need to take care of, and so what I would want is for us to treat the crisis like a crisis. That is the only way forward.Thunberg, who also founded the School Strike for Climate movement, described meeting Sir David as ldquotruly remarkable.She said: ldquoIt was an amazing opportunity. And it was something that I will never forget. I have spoken to him several times, I think, four times, but only online.ldquoAnd then I met him in person and it was truly remarkable. And it was something that I will never forget.ldquoHersquos such an extraordinary person who has been able to experience so much and has witnessed these changes really first-hand as they happened, from the beginning, from when we first became aware of these things.ldquoSo, of course, he has a perspective and a story that very few people have, definitely.In the series, Thunberg visits Canadarsquos Athabasca Glacier, which scientists tell her is melting faster than models had predicted, with a contributing factor being soot from surrounding forest fires falling on it.She also visits a coal mine in Europe, where she meets Polish workers who tell her about their fears for their industry and the mining culture.Thunberg said: ldquoBeing able to stand on top of a glacier and someone says lsquoThis will be gone soon, and therersquos no way of saving itrsquohellipldquoOf course, thatrsquos very emotional, and to meet people who have lost everything and to witness these kinds of events first-hand and to witness the consequences of the climate crisis and to meet the people who are actually being affected by it already today, thatrsquos very powerful.ldquoBut also meeting people like the Polish coal miners, that was a very, very important meeting, and also very moving.ldquoI made many dferent interviews as well that didnrsquot make it in the final cuts, but they were just as important and just as incredible to be able to experience.ndash Greta Thunberg: A Year To Change The World begins on BBC One on April  at pm.

title: george-galloway-accuses-bbc-seeded-nationalists
story: The lead candidate of the pro-union party All for Unity spent most of the interview dodging questions on whether he believed Vladimir Putins Russia was behind the poisoning of the Skripals in Salisbury in .He also claimed that businesseshad left Dumfries and Galloway as a result of talk over a second independence referendum, but failed to cite any examples when repeatedly asked -calling the question "silly".It follows an interviewwith Alba Party leader Alex Salmond on Wednesday morning, in which he was also quizzed about the Salisbury poisonings.:Salmond labelled Putin apologist for downplaying Russias actionsMr Skripal, a former Russian spy turned double agent for MI, and his -year-old daughter were left seriously ill after coming into contact with the deadly nerve agent Novichok.Speaking on Good Morning Scotland on Wednesday, Mr Salmond refused to say three times whether Russia was behind the Salisbury poisonings - as he was grilled about his programme on Kremlin-backed television.Both Galloway and Salmond workfor RT, formerly Russia Today.Presenter and journalist Laura Maciver asked the formerLabour MP George Gallowayhe believed Russia interfered in the  independence referendum or in either of the last two US presidential elections.He replied: "Well its very odd that the thesis is that the Russians want to break-up Britain, and they want to encourage separatism when they employ me as one of the main hammers of nationalist and separatism."Its a very odd charge, unless the allegation is that Putin is so canny a gambler hes got money on Alex Salmond and me, hes betting on separatism and union - its all very silly."He added: "I have never been interfered with by the Russians, and Im not sure I can safely say that for the people presenting programmes on the BBC."Two days in a row @BBCScotlandNews have turned interviews with me into Russia-baiting hunt-the-Putin. The state-backed BBC calling other people state-backed. While thousands of Scottish pensioners were Man-slaughtered in the Care Homes...Following the interview, and a similarly uncomfortable grilling on BBCs The Nine last night, Galloway posted on Twitter accusing BBC Scotland of being a "festival against Britain".He said: "BBC Scotland is heavily seeded with Scottish Nationalists."They hate the Crown but they live well on its half-crown. Their counterparts where in the corporation ooze euromania and identity-politics liberalism.:George Galloway to launch legal action after being excluded from BBC and STV leader debate"Together they are quite a Festival against Britain."Two days in a row @BBCScotlandNews have turned interviews with me into Russia-baiting hunt-the-Putin."The state-backed BBC calling other people state-backed. While thousands of Scottish pensioners were Man-slaughtered in the Care Homes..."

title: review-mg-zs-ev-suv
story: Ifyoursquorelookingfor the same thing, thenthe compact family-sizedMG ZS EVdelivers.Itrsquosan SUV, itrsquos battery electric,its well-equippedand above all,itrsquosvery affordable. Ifyoursquoreworking to a budget and donrsquot need the ultimatewhen it comes torange, then you might like what the ZS EV has to offer.BackgroundInterest in electric vehicle technology is growing at a rapid pace, but price continues to be a barrierfor some. Enter the MG ZS EV. Priced to undercut its rivals by a signicant margin,itrsquoseven cheaper than some supermini EVs.The ZS has been around for a while. The spacious compact SUV was launched in  with a choice of .-litre or .-litre petrol engines. However, MG had their eye on full electrication from thevery outset and designed the ZS  with that goal in mind.Driving ExperienceThe ZS EV is powered by a .kWh, water-cooled lithium-ion battery which delivers a WLTP-rated driving range of  miles.Itrsquosnot quite cutting-edgewhencompared to comparable family EVs which manage miles from a single charge ndash but those cars are signicantly more expensive and are less spacious to boot.As with any EV, the ZS EV is quick off the mark withan immediateNm of torque.Therersquos kW of power-the equivalent of PS-which will see you hit mph in just . seconds.However, off-the-line performanceisnrsquotquite matched by top speed which is limited to mph.At the wheeltherersquosa nty Rotary Gear Selector in place of the usual gear stick, offering the choice of Drive, Neutral and Reverse, coupled with aswitch that allows you to select between three levels of braking energy recoveryLevel one provides a small amount of regeneration whilst requiring much the same braking action on the part of the driver whilstlevelthreeoffersa near one-pedal driving experience with maximum braking regeneration kicking inas soon as the accelerator is lted.Once you get used to it, this level provides an easier drive, improves overallefficiency,and reduces overall wear on parts. Clever stuff.Design and BuildMG has done a great job with the styling.At a smidge over .m in the ZS EVsits between smaller crossovers like the Nissan Juke and larger family-sized crossovers like the Kia Sportage. It also sports a couple of model-specic features such as the updated lsquostar-riderrsquo front grille which frames the iconic octagonal badge andtherersquosa unique colour option which MG call lsquoPimlico Bluersquo.Without exception, every EV model under the pound, price markisconsiderablysmaller than the ZS EV ndash both inside and out.The battery pack has been carefully positioned beneath the car to avoid eating into valuable passenger or luggage space. The -litre boot capacity offers around -litres more than a standard compact SUV making it capable of handling bulky loads with easefrombikesandpramstocopious amount of IKEA flat-pack.Of course,the interiorisnrsquotquite up to the same standard as some of the moreestablished brands. Butthatrsquosnot to say the cabin feels cheap. MG has done a very good job outfitting the interior with faux-leather upholstery and a pleasing array of metallic and chrome finishes which belie its price point.Market and ModelTherersquosa choice of two trim levels, lsquoExcitersquo and lsquoExclusiversquo. Once the governmentrsquos Plug-in Car Grant has been deducted,thelist pricesarearoundpound,andpound,respectively.Thatrsquosexceptional value. To put that into context, anequivalently sizedEVcrossover like the Kia e-Niro starts at around pound,. Even smaller supermini EVs such as the Corsa-e and the Peugeot ewill set you back at leastpound,. Whilst these models offer greater rangethan the ZS EV, for the typical suburbanmotorist that the ZS EV is aimed at, range may not be a huge issue.Equipment levels arealsostrongwith both iants benefitting from MGrsquos latest infotainment system which comes with an  colour touchscreen featuring sat nav, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay support, Bluetooth phone connectivity with audio streaming and DAB radio.The rather fetchingEV-specic  diamond-cutalloys are also standard. An optionalglass sliding Sky Roofoffers a splash of style andtheres also the brands MG Pilot camera safety package which includes Advanced Emergency Braking, Blindspot Monitoring, Lane Keep Assist and Adaptive Cruise Control.Cost of OwnershipThe WLTP-rated range is  miles which rises to  miles on the WLTP city cycle. Charging is simple enoughthanks to a combined CSS and Type  socket conveniently mounted on the front grille for easy access from either side of the vehicle.TheCSSsocketoffers rapid charging from a kW public charger which will deliver  to % charge in just  minutes.Ifyoursquorecharging at home using a standard kWwallboxyoursquoll be all done in six hours, so overnight charging is a breeze. Ifyoursquorereallystuck,you can use a standard -pin plugndash though yoursquod have to be really desperate or have plenty of time on your hands. The battery pack weighs just Kg providing competitive emission-free performance. MG has developeditsown lsquoIntelligent Battery Temperature Controlrsquo system which insulates the battery pack from external temperature iationsdeliveringthe optimum power and range in all weather conditions. Both iants also benefit from MGrsquossevenyear , miles warranty package ndash the longest fully transferable warranty in its class and two years more than rivals such as Hyundai and Toyota.SummaryMG has delivered a typicallytightly pricedpackagethatdemonstratesjust how affordable afamily-sizedEVcan be. Whilst rangeisnrsquotthe best,yoursquore mainly an urban driver the ZS EV, withitsspacious interior, good levels of equipment and exceptional transferrable warranty, might just be the cheap, electric SUV yoursquorelooking for.Isitthe best initssector No. Is it an impressively affordable model initsclass Absolutely.Considering the MGZS asyour next car View ourMG ZSoffersBrought to you by Intelligent Car Leasing

title: scotlands-railways-face-new-disruption-weekend-scotrail-conductors-strike
story: The rail union RMT said the action involving ScotRail conductors is going ahead on Sunday as the company is "refusing point blank" to engage in talks aimed at addressing the issue of "equality over enhanced payments for rest day working.The union says that two days of action in the dispute so far have been solidly supported the across the franchise which is operated by state-owned Dutch train operator Abellio.RMT says this reinforces the anger of staff at the companyrsquos "wholesale failure to treat their conductors with the fairness and equality with other grades that they so clearly deserve".The run of strikes were due to take place on Sundays till May  ndash and could potentially be extendedno deal is reached with the company.RMT says that Abellio, in the dying months of their franchise, are "quite happy to cancel services wholesale rather than engage in serious talks with the union as they seek to milk every last penny out their ScotRail contract before they are kicked out".In a separate dispute around the same issue RMT ticket examiner members voted overwhelmingly for action on Thursday and the unionrsquos executive will be deciding on tactics with that mandate in hand.ScotRail warned customers to expect "signicant travel disruption" on Easter Sunday because of the strike action by the RMT during the COVID- pandemic.It said the action was aimed at increasing overtime payments at a time "when ScotRail is facing its worst ever financial crisis".It has warned that the action would have a "signicant impact on people who need to travel, including NHS workers delivering a critical service during the pandemic".:ScotRail attacks reckless union bosses as it faces new strike action after ticket examiners ballot"The strike comes with passenger numbers and revenue down more than  per cent compared to before the pandemic. Coronavirus restrictions, including the instruction for people to work from home, have resulted in the number of people travelling with ScotRail to plummet," it said."Throughout the pandemic, ScotRail has continued to provide services for key workers who are reliant on trains to get them to work in order to perform le-saving duties on the emergency front-line, hospitals, and care homes. The railway is now supporting the rollout of the vaccine."The RMT balloted its conductor members despite all ScotRail jobs being protected thanks to emergency Scottish Government support, with no staff placed on furlough or any cuts to basic wages or terms and conditions."It said an emergency measures agreementhas been agreed with the Scottish Government, which will continue until at least September , and means ScotRail can continue to operate services for key workers and keep its , staff in secure jobs.But RMT general secretary Mick Cash said that the political leadership in Scotland can "no longer sit on the fence and ignore these disputes in their back yard".He said: ldquoI want to pay tribute to our ScotRail conductors who have stood firm from day one in this dispute in a fight for basic pay justice and equality with other grades. It is frankly disgusting that these same staff, who have kept Scotlandrsquos key workers moving during the pandemic, have been repaid with a kick in the teeth from this greedy and aggressive company.ldquoAbellio are happy to keep this dispute running, cancel services and bleed the franchise dry rather than engaging in serious talks over workplace justice with the union. That is a disgrace."Its time for serious talks, a serious approach to workplace fairness and justice and a serious solution to lrmbe reached.ldquoOur action goes ahead on Sunday and the union stands shoulder to shoulder with our conductor members.ScotRail has received more than pound million in extra government subsidy to allow it to operate a service for key workers and pay staff wages in this year alone.Members of the RMT trade union voted  to  in favour of strike action in the ticket examiners dispute and  over  for industrial action short of a strike.It is not yet known whether any action will take place on the same days as strikes being carried out by conductors.ScotRail claimed conductors are trying to force an increase in overtime payments during the coronavirus pandemic.The rail firm is now awaiting further information from RMT over the outcome of the ticket examiner vote and its potential impact on trainservices.

title: jet2-suspends-flights-holidays-late-june-amid-uncertainty-government-travel-rules
story: Customers with the Jet airline can expect flights and holidays to be suspended until at least  June.It comes as Transport Secretary Grant Shapps this morning said people can ldquostart to think about booking overseas summer holidays.:Greta Thunberg wont attend Glasgow summit as COP should be postponedThe Cabinet minister said it is the first time in ldquomany months he was not advising against booking foreign trips.His comments came just five days after Downing Street published a document which urged people ldquonot to book summer holidays abroad until the picture is clearer.On Friday Mr Shapps announced a ldquoframework for the resumption of overseas leisure travel, which included requiring all arrivals to take pre-departure and post-arrival coronavirus tests.Post-arrival tests must be the polymerase chain reactiontype which cost about pound, he said.This led to a furious backlash from the travel industry, which wants travellers ing from low-risk countries to be allowed to take lateral flow tests, which are cheaper and quicker.Askedpeople could start to book foreign holidays now, Mr Shapps told Sky News: ldquoIrsquom not telling people that they shouldnrsquot book summer holidays now, itrsquos the first time that Irsquove been able to say that for many months.He said he was looking to ldquodrive down the costs of tests required for international travel to resume.ldquoCosts are definitely a concern, itrsquos one of the factors this year, and we have to accept wersquore still going through a global pandemic, he said.ldquoAnd so we do have to be cautious and Irsquom afraid that does involve having to have some tests and the like.ldquoBut, I am undertaking today to drive down the costs of those tests and looking at some innovative things we could do.EasyJet chief executive Johan Lundgren said the requirement for PCR tests was ldquoa blow to all travellers and risked ldquomaking flying only for the wealthy.He added: ldquoAs the rest of British society and the economy opens up, it makes no sense to treat travel, particularly to low-risk countries, dferently.Mark Tanzer, boss of travel trade organisation Abta, said permitting the use of lateral flow tests would ldquomake international travel more accessible and affordable whilst still providing an effective mitigation against reimportation of the virus.Tim Alderslade, chief executive of Airlines UK, the industry body representing UK-registered carriers, said the announcement ldquodoes not represent a reopening of travel as promised by ministers.The Department for Transportrefused to confirm whether foreign holidays will be permitted from May , which is the earliest date under the Prime Ministerrsquos road map for easing coronavirus restrictions in England.The Global Travel Taskforce report has set out the approach to safely restart international travel. This will ensure businesses and the economy continue to grow as well as helping reconnect families across the globe.##More on the report #https:t.co HWiUHEeHiN #TravelSafelymdash Department for TransportApril , It also insisted it was ldquotoo early to predict which countries will be on which list under a new risk-based traffic light system, with an ldquoinitial assessment to be produced ldquoby early May.People arriving from a ldquogreen country will not be required to self-isolate, but those entering the UK from an ldquoamber destination must quarantine for  days.Existing rules for arrivals from ldquored locations will continue, including the requirement to pay to enter a quarantine hotel.These restrictions will be ldquoformally reviewed on June  to take account of ldquothe domestic and international health picture and to see whether current measures could be rolled back, the DfT added.Further reviews will take place no later than July  and October .A ldquoGreen Watchlist will be introduced to identy countries most at risk of moving from ldquogreen to ldquoamber.

title: scottish-labour-give-everyone-75-boost-high-street-recovery
story: Leader Anas Sarwar said the poundmillion proposal would be the largest and most radical economic stimulus plan in the history of devolution.ldquoThis is a chance to reward Scottish families for their sacrices in the last year and help keep fellow Scots in work to support our national recovery, he said.Under the plan, .m people aged  or over would get a prepaid card which could only be spent in a physical premises - not online - and would be valid for six months.It would be limited to ldquonon-food retail, as supermarkets have managed relatively well during lockdown.The cards could also not be used to buy tobacco or alcohol, transferred to savings, or spent on household bills or gambling.Any unused money would be donated to foodbanks.The idea is a massively scaled up version of a poundm scheme in Jersey, where residents were given pound vouchers last year as part of a Covid recovery plan.More than a quarter of the money there went on food and bills, something not possible under the Labour plan.Labour also said it wanted to boost the Scottish tourist industry by offering people a third free night in holiday accommodation ina ldquoGreat Scottish Staycation scheme.It would be accompanied by a lsquoScotland is openrsquo campaign to welcome visitors from across the UK.Any tourist travelling within or to Scotland from the British Isles in September, October and November would be eligible, with up to pound available per person towards the cost of their third night, capped at pound per hotel room or pound per person in other accommodation.The package is aimed at encouraging shoppers and tourists to support local economies, when safe, and ldquoredressing the balance following the boom for large online retailers.Mr Sarwar said: ldquoThe last year has been tough for us all. The pandemic has separated us from our friends, families and neighbours.ldquoBut amid the hope of an end to the public health emergency, we must recognise that Scotland still faces a job crisis.ldquoWithout urgent and ambitious action in towns across this country, hundreds of thousands of people face a future out of work - with empty town centres hollowing out once vibrant communities.ldquoBut it doesnrsquot have to be that way - the people of Scotland deserve a brighter future, and we have it in our power to act.ldquoThis is bold and ambitious thinking to aid our economic recovery and get Scotland back on track.ldquoThis scheme would invite people from across the UK to visit every corner of our beautul country - saving jobs and creating a lelong love of Scotland.He added: ldquoThis is a chance to reward Scottish families for their sacrices in the last year and help keep fellow Scots in work to support our national recovery.ldquoA vote for us at this election is for a parliament focused on solutions, not isions - a stronger recovery for every community and every family.

title: covid-scotland-glasgow-gyms-swimming-pools-museums-among-90-venues-reopening
story: Venues including Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, Riverside Museum and the Emirates Arena will reopen on Monday April .The Mitchell Library will welcome people again the following day, with other sites such as Hillhead Library, Linn Park Adventure Playground and Glasgow BMX Centre following suit in the subsequent weeks.Kelvingrove GalleryVisitor numbers will be restricted due to social distancing required indoors, but a number of libraries and outdoor sports venues have already reopened in line with Scottish Government guidance.Eleven venues operated by Glasgow Le will continue to be used by NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde as part of the nationwide Covid- testing and vaccination programme including the Riverside Museum car park.Dr Bridget McConnell, Glasgow Le chief executive, said: ldquoAs one of Scotlandrsquos largest charities, Glasgow Le is at the heart of Glasgowrsquos communities.ldquoWe deliver some of the cityrsquos most used and most valued services, and we care passionately about what we do.Mitchell LibraryldquoThe coronavirus pandemic has had a devastating impact, but with the easing of Scottish Government restrictions from the end of April, people will once again be able to access many of the Glasgow Le services they enjoy and rely on.ldquoVisits will look a little dferent as we ensure that facilities are safe for everyone.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming people back into our cityrsquos museums, libraries and sports facilities in the weeks and months ahead.Key Glasgow venues and when they reopenClick here for a full list of venues reopening.

title: former-council-provost-becomes-latest-snp-figure-back-salmonds-alba-party
story: Celia Lawsonserved as an SNP councillor for more than  yearsand was provost of Renfrewshire from  to .She said: "I am delighted to endorse the Alba Party in the upcoming Scottish Parliament elections."People in the West of Scotland can make a huge dference to helping deliver a supermajority for independence."My message to SNP voters is to vote for the SNP in your constituency but give your list vote to Albaand make both votes count for Yes to independence."We saw in  that SNP votes were totally wasted in ing zero MSPs on the list locally allowing Tories to sneak in."There were over , SNP votes on the regional list in the West of Scotland which ed not a single independence-supporting MSP."If these votes go to Albathis time round we willall four excellent Albacandidates."This time we can make a real dference in the West of Scotland and elect AlbaMSPs who will not only fight for the west but fight for independence in the next Parliament."Mr Salmond said: "Celia was a well respected councillor, and provost, in the West of Scotland for two decades so to have her support for Albais a tremendous boost for our campaign and one that will resonate with people in Renfrewshire and the west."MsLawson is the latest in a string of SNP figures to back Alba.

title: nicola-sturgeon-sends-deepest-condolences-royal-family-scotlands-behalf
story: Buckingham Palace said Prince Philip, who had been married to the Queen for  years, died peacefully this morning at Windsor Castle.Parties suspended campaigning for the Holyrood election.The First Minister sent her ldquopersonal and deepest condolences and those of the Scottish Government and Scottish people to the Queen and her family.I am saddened by news that the Duke of Edinburgh has died. I send my personal and deepest condolences - and those of @scotgov and the people of Scotland - to Her Majesty The Queen and her family. https:t.co GocXXOHUScottish Toryleader Douglas Rosscalled the Prince a "tremendous public servant who for decades served his Queen and country".He said: "In the middle of a political campaign, this is a reminder of whatrsquos most important in le.ldquoWe have lost a tremendous public servant who for decades served his Queen and country. My heartfelt condolences are with Her Majesty and all of the Royal Family.ldquoWe have suspended our campaign effective immediately.In the middle of a political campaign, this is a reminder of whatrsquos most important in le.We have lost a tremendous public servant who for decades served his Queen and country. My heartfelt condolences are with Her Majesty and all of the Royal Family.Former First Minister Alex Salmond, now leader of the Alba Party, said:ldquoOn behalf of the AlbaParty, my condolences go to Her Majesty the Queen. The Duke of Edinburgh was the longest serving consort in history and no-one can question that record of public service."The Duke of Edinburgh Awards gave hope and purpose to generations of young people. On a personal level I found Prince Phillip direct and forthright but always welcoming and with a fine, enquiring mind.ScottishLabour leader Anas Sarwarsaid: "Scotland is today mourning the loss of a dedicated public servant who contributed so much to our country.ldquoMy thoughts are with Her Majesty the Queen following the death of her beloved husband and the entire Royal Family, and on behalf of the Scottish Labour Party I offer our sincerest sympathies.ldquoPrince Philip had a deep love for Scotland and we will now come together as a country to remember his le and mark his distinguished career.Scotland is today mourning the loss of the Duke of Edinburgh - a dedicated public servant.My thoughts are with Her Majesty The Queen following the death of her beloved husband  the entire Royal Family.On behalf of the Scottish Labour Party, I offer our deepest sympathies.The Palace said: ldquoIt is with deep sorrow that Her Majesty The Queen announces the death of her beloved husband, His Royal Highness The Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.ldquoHis Royal Highness passed away peacefully this morning at Windsor Castle.ldquoFurther announcements will made in due course.ldquoThe Royal Family join with people around the world in mourning his loss.

title: astrazeneca vaccine not to be offered to orkney adults under 30
story: Adults under  in Orkney will only be offered the Pfizer COVID- vaccine — for the time being — NHS Orkney has confirmed.This news follows international concern over potential side effects related to the AstraZeneca vaccine.The announcement came, this morning, Friday, from NHSO director of Public Health, Dr Louise Wilson.Dr Wilson explained that, guidance around the use of AstraZeneca has changed due to an ongoing review into a very rare blood clotting problem affecting a small number of people worldwide, which may be linked to the vaccine.People  or over will continue to be offered either the AstraZeneca or Pfizer vaccine. However, while investigations continue into its effects,  to -year-olds will not be offered the Astra Zeneca unless there is an inidual medical reason why that brand might be preferable. At this stage, NHS Orkney is not expecting to receive any supply of the Moderna vaccine.If you have already received one dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine, you will still be offered AstraZeneca as your second dose.Dr Wilson explained that the blood clotting problem which is being reported is one which is very rare, but appears to be more prevalent in younger people. Overall, she believes that the risk of severe illness from COVID- far outweighs the risk from receiving the vaccine.She said: #Although the risk of developing this very rare clotting problem is very low indeed, people are advised to be aware of any of the following symptoms occurring between four days and four weeks after vaccination and to seek immediate medical adviceyou develop any of them:#These symptoms can be caused by many other conditions, and evennot caused by this rare specic clotting problem, they could indicate another condition that needs to be assessed.#COVID%vaccine%and%blood%clotting%leaflet_English.pdfcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new operator sought for ferry route
story: Orkney Islands Council is tendering for a new operator to run one of Orkney’s shortest regular ferry services, on behalf of Orkney Ferries.The service, from Pierowall in Westray to Papa Westray, is usually operated by a North Isles crew on behalf of Orkney Ferries — but OIC has confirmed the service provider, Malcolm Brown from Westray is due to retire, resulting in a market test for a new operator.The mv Nordic Sea is expected to become the vessel for this service later this year — but has been undergoing a near £, refit in Buckie since January, to prepare her for UK certication as a passenger ferry. The vessel was purchased for close to £million to replace the mv Golden Mariana.However, the procurement process for the new operator is open to the mv Nordic Sea not being used at all.Jim Buck, OIC harbour master and head of marine services and transportation, said: “We expect that most potential operators would opt to use the Nordic Sea on the Westray to Papa Westray service.“But, to keep the procurement process as open as possible, and make sure we are getting best value, we are also happy to hear from potential operators with an interest in using a suitable vessel of their own on the route.“We think this is unlikely, but were that to happen, the Nordic Sea is a very capable vessel, and would be used to support services where in the network as a core part of the overall Orkney Ferries’ fleet.”Full story in this week#s The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic not consulted on scotgov lockdown survey
story: Orkney Islands Councilleader James Stockan has confirmed OIC were #not consulted# on the islands survey recently published by the Scottish Government, that asked islanders on how they wanted lockdown restrictions to be eased.Councillor Stockan said: #The national consultation and survey happened very quickly, and local authorities were unaware of this happening, and not consulted on the two options presented, until we were advised by members of our community.#When we became aware of it, we were keen to encourage those who had received it to respond by the deadline.#The survey askedislanders wished to either remain in Level Three — which would allow for travel to the Scottish mainland — or to drop into lower a Level without the ability to travel. A third option of #other# was also presented.This dfered with the view of OIC, who on the same day called on the government to drop Orkney into its lowest possible level, as well as scrapping travel restrictions.Councillor Stockan said: #Decisions as to how best that can happen for Orkney are made as a collective.#The position we arrived at as a council was also taken after y discussions with the two island leaders of Shetland and the Western Isles, and we all came to the same conclusion.#However, there are now two options on the table from Scottish Government and no matter which is chosen as the preferred way forward, it will not suit everyone.#This leaves councillors with a dficult challenge ahead, but as a council, we are continuing to press for pre-travel testing before anyone arrives in Orkney, with more than one option in discussion.The survey#s two-day deadline was also met with several complaints online.See the full story in this week#s The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: when the bombs fell the orkney air raid
story: By Patricia LongThe little parish of Stenness suffered the worst effects of the German bombing raid on  March  but was not the only part of Orkney to be attacked#An extract from W. S. Hewison, This Great Harbour Scapa Flow, : #The enemy bombers came in from the east as darkness began to fall on Saturday evening,  March. Intelligence reports later put the number at  or  although some estimates were as high as  – it was dficult to make an accurate count as some of them ed out of the twilight while others made high-level attacks… #Their targets were the Fleet in Scapa and Hatston airfieldon Kirkwall Bay, with the attack starting at . pm and lasting a noisy, confused and hectic three-quarters of an hour.#The main attack on the Fleet was by eight aircraft in line-astern but breaking formation over the Flow itself as they selected their inidual targets. #The raid on Hatston was by five or six bombers flying fairly low. A total of nearly  HE and incendiary bombs were dropped on land, quite apart from those which fell in the sea, and there was no question this time of the German bomb-aimers forbearing to unleash their missiles at land-based targets. # bombs were dropped around Hatston where they did little damage and another  at the completely innocuous Brig of Waithe…#There was some indiscriminate machine-gun fire from a few of the bombers, as well as firing down searchlight beams. The blockships in Holm Sound were also bombed and machine-gunned, apparently in the mistaken belief that they were anchored merchant ships…#And once again the old Iron Duke, having been patched up and moved to Longhope [after being damaged in the first raid of the war on  October] was bombed for the second time with, however, little damage. Much more serious was the attack on the cruiser Norfolk which was hit and also holed by a near miss#This preview ends here. To read the full captivating story from Patricia Long, visit her blog on www.aboutorkneyPatricia Long is a tourist guide based in Stenness, with a particular interest in social history.The full article is also available in the April  edition of The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. But Philip was at her side. vw,vw,px, px"The Queen with the Duke of Edinburgh after the Queen Motherrsquos funeral There will be no chance to spend as much time as she needs to grieve out of the spotlight.An appearance at the dukersquos funeral in the full glare of the media beckons within days.The Queen, with all her training as head of state, is used to holding her emotions in check in public.Shortly after her father, King George VI, died, she was required to greet then prime minister Winston Churchill and other dignitaries immediately on ing to London from Kenya as the new Queen.But sometimes the depth of her sadness has proved too much.Just months after the Queen Mother died, tears rolled down her cheeks when she took on her late motherrsquos role at the poignant opening of the Field of Remembrance at Westminster Abbey. vw,vw,px, px"The Queen sheds a tear during the Field of Remembrance Service at Westminster Abbey in  During her Diamond Jubilee celebrations, she cut a solitary figure as she walked through St Paulrsquos Cathedral without the duke, who was in hospital with a bladder infection.Princess Eugenie, the couplersquos granddaughter, said the Queen and Philip were each otherrsquos ldquorock and spoke of how dficult it had been for the Queen to be without her husband during the jubilee events.ldquoThey are the most incredibly supportive couple to each other.ldquoGrandpa was unfortunately taken ill and for granny to come and do that alone was probably quite testing and I think he is her rock, really, and she is his, she told Sky News.The couple reached the rare personal milestone of their platinum wedding anniversary on November  ,  years of marriage, and, in a touching gesture, the Queen appointed Philip aKnight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order for his years of devotion and duty.They shared an irreplaceable bond, united at key moments of history, witnessed from the unique viewpoint of a monarch and her consort. vw,vw,px, px"The Queen with Philip as he signed the visitorsrsquo book at Hillsborough Castle While private secretaries and household staff have come and gone, Philip remained a constant in the Queenrsquos le.They travelled the globe together, endured state visit after state visit, and thousands of engagements over the years, all made more bearable with one anotherrsquos company and through the knowledge they were in it as a duo, albeit one wearing the crown.They also witnessed the changing world from a shared standpoint, with just five yearsrsquo dference in age between them.They married in the s andtogether saw the rapid advances in modern le from man walking on the moon for the first time to the invention of the internet.As duty dictates, the Queen will continue her role as sovereign without the le-long companion upon whom she greatly depended.copy -.
