title: Car SOS team restores famous 6R4 rally car
story: FOR petrol heads everywhere, National Geographicrsquos Car SOS television show is compelling viewing.Now in its ninth series, the show saves decaying cars from the scrapheap by revitalising and rebuilding them for their richly deserved, but unsuspecting owners.The show mdash which highlights the mercurial talents of master mechanic Fuzz Townsend and the extrovert and persuasive parts-blagging skills of Tim Shaw mdash is hugely popular.And while it is a must watch for petrol heads, it also compulsive viewing for those interested in heart-warning stories where families contact Car SOS asking for the car of a loved one who is no longer able to complete the project for a iety of reasons, particularly illness, to be restored.The show has the ability to provide a detailed insight into the amazing world of car restoration and the tricks of the trade, but it also has an unerring ability to tug at the heart strings and has even been known to make grown men cry.The all-important lsquorevealrsquo at the showrsquos climax is emotional, not only for the families involved, but viewers, with hardened petrol heads claiming to have something in their eye as they wipe away a tear or two.One of the most recent episodes featured a famous MGR rally car saved from the scrapheap by Loughinisland man Brian McKayto restore with the help of his son, Gerard .The iconic s car had been driven by Scottish rally legend David Gillanders on the Group B world rally circuit and won British National Rally Championship in .However, the Group B competition was short-lived as it was abandoned after a string of high-profile driver and spectator fatalities which consigned the  brake horsepowerto the history books.Saved from the scrapyard in South Armagh by rally enthusiasts Brian and Gerard, they put in place a restoration project for the infamous R, but there was no timescale in place for what they knew would be a labour of love.Spending a few nights each week and some weekends working on the car was the plan, in between saving to buy key parts which were not only expensive, but very dficult to source at times.Sadly, Brian suffered a stroke and the arrival of a global pandemic threw another spanner in the restoration works. While it seemed the rebuild of the R would take signicantly longer than the father and son team anticipated, Car SOS changed all that after Brianrsquos daughter, Libby, contacted the programme makers who were quick to realise the signicance and history of the car the McKay family now owned.Gerard said the road to the Car SOS reveal at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel in Ballynahinch at the end of last summer began in  when a family friend alerted them to the whereabouts of the iconic car mdash which was lying on its side mdash in a scrapyard in Crossmaglen.ldquoWe did not know the full history of the car at this stage, but we did know that it was famous across Ireland as it was driven by John Moloney, whom I used to watch driving it at Mondello Park when I was much younger, he explained.ldquoJohn was was very successful and won a number of Irish Rally Championships with the R which was one of the first of its kind to compete in Ireland.ldquoWhen Dad and I bought the car it was a shell. I had always wanted to get my hands on Moloneyrsquos red and white R and was delighted to discover it was the very one that we now owned. While it needed major surgery, I was nonetheless delighted to have a car with such pedigree. However, we did not know the full history of the R at that stage.Gerard explained that when the car was brought home, neither he nor his father knew about the link with David Gillanders and what R they really had on their hands.ldquoA family friend from Leitrim, Eamonn McAleenan, initially told us about the car and when we got it back to Loughinisland he told us it was famous. When we replied, lsquoWe know, it was John Moloneyrsquosrsquo, Eamonn said, lsquoNo, I mean it is really famousrsquo and revealed that it was David Gillanders car. We couldnrsquot believe it.ldquoThe rally community is very small and everyone knows about cars, where they came from and who owned and drove them. When Moloney racedthe car it was probably the talk of the country as it was an Austin Rover works car, but when we hauled it out of the scrapyard we had no idea what we had really bought.Gerard said his father knew who Eamonn was talking about and recalled seeing images of the car in the Motoring News magazine.ldquoWe did our homework and, sure enough, it was Gillanderrsquos R and we had this confirmed by someone inEngland who is something of an expert in the MGcars. We knew that we had the real deal, he continued.ldquoA mechanical manual came with the car which would help us get it back on the road again. It was pre-Facebook at this stage but when I put a photo of the car on the internet, it literally exploded with messages.ldquoIt is hard to believe that the car was in a scrapyard for  years. When we bought it in , the car had been stripped for parts and the shell was getting tired. When we got to the scrapyard it had been sitting on top of some tyres but had fallen over on to its side.Gerard said he was ldquodoing handstands as he had got his hands on Moloneyrsquos car, explaining that being the owner of the vehicle with his father ldquowas the ultimate for him. He said when he put the car on the internet many people commented that they thought Gillanders car had been lost.When it came to rebuilding the car, Gerard and his father had the engine, gearbox and two out of the three dfs. They ended up getting a third from a Peugeot  they purchased.With Gerard moving to England for five years, no work was done on the car which was left in a garage with a cover over it, but in  the R was moved from Loughinisland to his garage in Castlewellan.ldquoDad was a mechanic and I am a joiner by trade while another friend of mine, Frank McMullan, helped with the bodywork. We got the shell back into shape and then started getting the  on but Dad then had a stroke so the work stopped. For me, there were more important things to worry about. That was fine as restoring the R was always going to be a long-term project anyway. It was labour of love.Just weeks before last yearrsquos lockdown, Fuzz and Tim rocked up to take the R back to England for its makeover after being contacted by Gerardrsquos sister and with the team one week away from completing the job, work had to stop due to Covid-.ldquoIncredibly, the work on the car was completed within about six weeks as a -strong team was working on it. They also had a very firm foundation to start with which helped, Gerard explained.In the build-up to the big reveal, the McKay family was due to go to England at the end of last March, but this wasnrsquot possible due to lockdown restrictions, so the unveiling was put on hold until last August.However, Brian and Gerard had no idea what was happening and arrived at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel for a family meal. And they couldnrsquot believe their luck when they saw David Gillanders sitting in the reception area.They told the rally driver that they owned his car and when they all went outside and saw a television crew and Fuzz rocking up in the gleaming R, they thought it was a programme involving the famous Scottish driver.ldquoI recognised Tim right away as Dad and I watch Car SOS and was not surprised to see him as I thought everything was focused on Gillanders. Then Tim spoke to Dad and I by name which really threw me. Then he said it was our car.ldquoIt was a pretty surreal moment and when we got to take the car for a drive it was incredible. The heat and noise of one of the most powerful rally car engines on the planet sitting over your left shoulder is an amazing feeling.ldquoWhat we now have is a museum quality car which is incredible and it certainly wonrsquot be raced. We will take it to shows and maybe some demonstration runs, but that will be it. Its competition days are over.Gerard added: ldquoThe reveal of the car was very emotional for Dad who thought all his Christmases had come at once. The R is everything we expected and more. Dad thought he would never have seen the car finished and is running about ashe is  again.ldquoI always thought that one day I would have been able to get the car back on the road as a petrol head never gives up on his dream. While I am sure I would have achieved my goal, what the Car SOS team has done is miraculous.ldquoWe are just a normal family which is car mad. Fuzz and Tim are gentlemen and a pleasure to work with. They are so down to earth and we canrsquot thank them or the Car SOS team enough. They were brilliant..prettyPhoto

title: Coach Conor gets call up
story: KILLYLEAGH goalkeeper Conor Brennan has been helping Northern Irelandrsquos U-s in a training camp ahead of their Euro qualiers later this year.The Glasgow Rangers Academy goalkeeping coach was drafted into newly appointed manager Gerard Lyttlersquos set-up after former Manchester United lsquokeeper Roy Carroll was required for duties with the senior squad.ldquoGerard gave me a ring to seeI could fly over from Scotland after Roy got the call up to help with the seniors, he said.ldquoI spoke to Rangers as I obviously am firstly employed with them, but they were more than happy for me to move on over. Therersquos three lads in the international team who are also on Rangers U- set up so I could keep an eye on them as well.Brennanwho also plays for East Kilbride FC in Scotlandrsquos Lowland Football League, joined the back room staff to help benefit the U- team after their Euro campaign was cancelled due to the Covid- pandemic.The team was set to play three qualiers in Sweden throughout March but those were cancelled. The camp was used ahead of the sides Euro  qualiers which take place in October.ldquoI was analysing what the team could do. A lot of stuff I was doing with them wasvery basic, such as handling and reflex drills. Some people may think that they should be the best in the country at their age but we are in the middle of a pandemic so its important to have that in your mind.ldquoNot all of the team are getting the game time they need through no fault of their own.The recent camp lasted from Monday to Friday, with manager Lyttle drafting in fellow countryman and former Rangers defender Gareth McAuley alongside the Killyleagh custodian.ldquoGarethrsquos experience and his calibre was great for the lads, they all grew up watching him play and now hersquos looking ahead to mould the future said Brennan.ldquoThe U-s are trying to get a few friendlies alongside a few training camps to keep busy. Gerard is trying to bring new players and staff together to see what the people are about. Having Gareth involved in the team is a no brainer.Brennan had the opportunity to work with promising young goalkeepers Conor Manderson from Portsmouth FC, and Dungannon Swtsrsquo Conner Bryne during the camp.Northampton Townrsquos Dylan Berry had to withdrawal from the camp after being called up to his clubrsquos senior team.ldquoThe young lsquokeepers are showing a lot of promise, this is why Gerard arranged the camp, Brennan continued. We want them to develop into future senior team internationals and have them playing at the highest level possible.As for the Killyleagh man himself, Brennan highlighted his aspirations for both his own playing and coaching career.ldquoI want to continue to keep doing as I am doing. People forget because of my coaching that I am still a player. I still enjoy the feeling of getting out on the pitch and playing. Irsquom only , soi play my cards right I could be playing for at least another ten years.Scotlandrsquos Lowland League recently made the decision to end this season on a points per game basis after discussions with the Scottish FA took place.ldquoI am disappointed that the season at East Kilbride ended. It was a real sickener as we were going to give it a right good go, but ultimately what can we do. The club has been brilliant for me and I definitely want to get back there next season.Brennan has gone from strength to strength with Rangers as he enters his fourth coaching season at the Glasgow club.ldquoIts going really well at my forth season at Rangers. In terms of my set up, Irsquom the U- goalkeeping coach and itrsquos a job I love doing and Irsquom passionate about it.ldquoI was the youngest in the UK to have my Uefa goalkeeping A licence, so that was a big help in attracting Rangers.ldquoI am currently completing my outfield Uefa A licence which will add another string to my bow and I eventually aim to have a Uefa pro A licence a few years down the line.Brennan has left his door open for any future offers to assist with the international squad, insisting he is happy to help in any way he can where possible..prettyPhoto

title: Engineer was legend in motor sport
story: JAMES Nathaniel Brown served his apprenticeship at Stewartrsquos Motor Works in Downpatrick before the Second World War, later moving to work for the former Ulster Transport Authority.In late  he opened his Antrim Road garage in Ballynahinch with a loan from a family friend and what a sound investment it proved to be, spawning a long and distinguished family connection with motorcycle sport of ious types.Not long after his business opened, James Nathaniel Brown mdash or JN as he was affectionately known mdash developed a business and social relationship with the Herron family from Leitrim, outside Castlewellan.And the sports connection evolved from here when Jimmy and Wilfred Herron began to take an interest in competition in the form of grass track racing, with JN putting his considerable engineering skills to good use in preparing the machinery for the brothers.However, the grass tracking phase was fairly short lived, with the Herron boys turning their attention to road racing and Jimmy consistently obtaining good results, But he was somewhat outshone by Wilfred who in his first season in  developed at a spectacular pace, going from novice to a force to be reckoned with.The swtness of his rise through the ranks is illustrated by the result from the  North West  road race when, riding a cc Gold Star BSA, he finished third behind very distinguished international company in the shape of Jackie Wood and Bob Brown, the Australian who later rode works Matchless, Gilera and Honda machinery.Later that same year a Norton Featherbed was acquired just after the TT and, some six weeks later, Wilfie was in a stunning fth place in the World Championship Ulster Grand Prix when a split petrol tank forced race officials to black flag him with several laps to go.Wilfie subsequently finished that season tied on points with Louis Carter for the Walter Rusk trophy which was in effect the Irish road-race championship, with Jimmy backing this effort up by finishing fourth in the championship which covered all classes.In , Wilfie confirmed this form was no fluke by winning the Irish Championship, including a fth place finish at the Ulster Grand Prix to score two world championship points. He then repeated the feat in , scoring consistently all over Ireland.At this stage, Jimmy was always a top contender in the cc class and along with brother Wilfie the duo were a force to be reckoned with.The speed and reliability of the brothersrsquo machinery during this spell was clear proof of JN Brownrsquos meticulous approach to preparation and outstanding ability in the tuning stakes, establishing a reputation whichwas to be enhanced over the following years.From  on, business pressures enforced a break from competition for the Herron brothers but JNrsquos enthusiasm was undiminished and he turned his attention to the grass track and motocross scene and it was during this phase that he became more and more involved with engine development, compared to just preparation.JN began this era with a youngster by the name of Mervyn McConkey who would progress to legendary status in grass track and scrambling history, becoming Irish champion in every capacity class available. A feat that no one has ever matched.The machine chosen for this venture was the Triumph Tiger Cub, the cc class being very popular in Ireland for all types of racing and where the legendary Joey Dunlop started his illustrious career.McConkey showed great potential right from the word go and within weeks of his first race was starting to win on a regular basis. Indeed, before long he was a top contender in the cc, cc, cc and cc classes and there were occasions when he won every race he entered at a given meeting, with a seasonrsquos tally of wins almost topping the  mark.All this was of course greatly helped by JN Brownrsquos engine tuning and modication programme, with the development aspect of his activities accelerated with the acquisition of a cc BSA C-.Indeed, so successful was the Brown McConkey alliance that results came to the notice of the BSA factory in the shape of the companyrsquos competitions department manager Brian Martin, with whom JN established a successful and long-lived development partnership.The factory C-s were being successfully campaigned by future world champion Jeff Smith and Saturday afternoon scrambles were regularly televised on BBCrsquos Grandstand programme.JN would send to the factory details of modications which had proved successful in Ireland and, of course,something was tried and failed in Ireland then the factory avoided any adverse publicity. Over the followings number of seasons BSA quietly supplied free machinery each season for use as a development test bed.In addition, JN also began a series of specials by increasing engine capacities, using the time honoured lsquobitzarsquo method of adapting separate parts of other engines to alter bore and stroke measurements and so achieve the desired capacity.Examples of this process were cc and cc specials, both of which were successfully campaigned by McConkey and his son Junior Brown.The BSA factory was kept informed and developed the works machinery along similar lines in terms of cylinder capacities used. The high point of factory development came with Jeff Smith becoming World Champion in  and again in , with both championships achieved using cc engines which confirm the signicant input from the Ballynahinch engineer.The next chapter in JNrsquos story emanated in a roundabout way from the USA.Triumph had long had a large part of their export sales in America whose major race was the prestigious Daytona  which had become something of a Harley Davidson benefit, with the manufacturer taking  successive wins from  onwards.SuccessThis success was largely attributable to Harleyrsquos capacity advantage in running cc machines, whereas the overhead valve equipped opposition were restricted to a cc limit.Triumph dealers in America began pressing the factory for some more race development on the T model being used at Daytona, but this request received a cool reception from MD Edward Turner.Luckily enough, Triumphrsquos head of development, the brilliant Doug Hele, took up the gauntlet and with his dedicated team and working largely in their own time, undertook the race development work.They eventually reached the stage where they scooped the  and  Daytona events with riders Gary Nixon and Buddy Elmore and the production T was re-christened the Daytona model. Further work enabled Percy Tait to record podium places in the World Championship Grand Prix series.Back in Ballynahinch, JN began to see this as a challenge and reckoned he could do as well as the factory, or maybe even better.His son, John, bought a second-hand T for his father to work his magic on and, to house the engine, a frame and cycle parts from a  World Championship winning cc Mondial were bought from George Purvis. It subsequently transpired that George had actually rebuilt the frame. After considerable development work had been carried out performance figures were indeed impressive with the motor producing approximately  BHP at , RPM, comparing very favourably with the fully race designed and developed Manx Norton and Matchless G engines favoured by the majority of top riders of that era.Consider also that the published factory figures for the  T production bike was  BHP at , RPM, with top speed quoted as  MPH ndash the Brown racer, pulling a tall gearing, could hit mph.JNrsquos work paid off in quite spectacular fashion at the  Tandragee  where Mervyn McConkey finished second to the late great Brian Steenson on a G Seely and ahead of that seasonrsquos cc Irish road race champion on a Manx Norton mdash not a bad result for a grass  scrambles specialist using a production based engine.Some year later, I spoke to road racer Ian McGregor. Ian was small in stature, but huge in his racing achievements and said he loved riding that bike as it was small enough to be comfortable for his size, handled well and was very quick.For the following three or four seasons, the Triumph was ridden, with ying degrees of success, by a number of top road racers including Wilfie Herron, Tom Herron Whilst the machine was undoubtedly very quick and handled well, it proved to be a bit fragile. Hardly surprising, considering the very advanced state of tune applied to what was still basically a production roadster.In  Wilfie bought a Norton Commando for competition in the recently introduced cc class. He approached JN with a view to having the Brown magic applied to the preparation of the machine and this wasduly carried out, once again to startling effect.The combination which had proved so successful nearly  years before resumed in full swing. For the following couple of seasons Wilfie was once again the man to beat in his chosen class with a record of something like  wins from  races over this outstandingly successful period.Through the late s, the development of two-stroke machinery drove on and expanded into the higher capacity classes so successfully that it became a near impossibility to campaign a four-stroke with any hope of consistent success.Having been a dedicated four-stroke fan for so many years, the two-stroke dominance was almost an anathema to JN and, after a brief spell working with a Bultaco Pursang, he drted from active participation in the motorcycling scene, but did continue with some consultancy work with Cosworth regarding F car engines.In the late seventies and eighties JN and my brother, John, sponsored my rallycross sprint hillclimb Mini. With development help from JN, I was fortunate to quickly become a front runner. JN always said that % of winning is done in the workshop before the race meetings on the Saturday.In later years JN became great friends with Keith Duckworth, the English mechanical engineer famous for designing the Cosworth double four valve per cylinder engine and cylinder head. Jim was also great friends with Sir Frank Williams and Sir Patrick Head, who was technical director of the Williams F team.JN was also great friends with the Rev Harold Good who later became Moderator of the Methodist Church in Ireland, with the Brown family running motorsport events at Martinrsquos Quarry and McCormackrsquos Quarry in the eighties in Ballynahinch in aid of the local Methodist church building fund.Sadly, for the last two or three years of his le JN had dementia and found things dficult given the active le he had lived.His funeral in  was one of the largest ever seen at Lough Inch Cemetery in Ballynahinch and was attended by motorcyclists from far and near. Also in attendance and Formula  greats like Sir Frank Williams, Sir Patrick Head and Keith Duckworth.I will always remember JN as a great innovative pioneering engineer who was fired by his own initiative. The likes we will never see again.Meanwhile, the Brian Steenson Memorial Group is planning to have a chat show and talk about the le and work of JN Brown later this year when lockdown restrictions ease and the group. The group will also have a new memorial cup this year dedicated to JN which has been donated by his son Junior.The Brian Steenson group would like to wish founder member Trevor Lindsay best wishes as he recovers from illness, with their thoughts also with his we Margaret and family at this time..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C April 11%2C 2001
story: NEWCASTLE ndash Two of Down Districtrsquos biggest visitor attractions will be open this weekend, as moves continue to prevent the collapse of the Easter tourist season.The Department of Agriculture has bowed to signicant tourist industry pressure and agreed to reopen both Tollymore and Castlewellan Forest Parks which draw thousands of day trippers to the area.Both parks attract thousands of visitors over Easter and also boast the arearsquos largest touring caravan sites which are heavily used over the Easter period.Confirmation the gates at both Tollymore and Castlewellan are to open for business again came on Monday afternoon, just hours after the Department of Agriculture had warned they would remain closed. However, pressure was stepped up when it was revealed that staffing problems, and not the foot and mouth crisis, was the main reason for the closures.Virtually all the forest park staff are away on disinfecting duties, mainly at ports and border crossings and Department officials felt they could not be spared to open the forests.ARDGLASS ndash A yard of ale, talent contest and car pulling competitions are the stuff of which traditional summer festivals are made.And according to the newly elected committee set up to bring Ardglass Festival back to le, these are examples of the old fashioned games most people prefer.The committee which was elected following the grouprsquos annual general meeting recently, has already announced the revival of the annual event which has not been staged since .The festival, which was one of the most popular events in the district for several years, was cancelled because of lack of interest but  local people have now volunteered to organise an events programme once again this year.BALLYNAHINCH ndash A Ballynahinch councillor is this week standing by his claims that thousands more vehicles are passing through Ballynahinch each day than officially acknowledged.Mr Francis Casement said while he is not prepared to reveal the source of his information, he says the figure he produced three weeks ago were compiled by the Roads Service and are accurate.The SDLP councillor produced daily traffic figures for several parts of the town which showed that over , vehicles pass through High Street.His comments come one week after Down Districtrsquos Divisional Roads Manager, Mr Sean Price, wrote to the Down Recorder, claiming the figures quoted by the local councillor in March were ldquocompletely erroneous and not based on departmental surveys.Mr Price said he has already informed Mr Casement about this and asked him to be more precise in ldquoidentying the source to enable him to shed some light on the confusion the figures have created.KILLYLEAGH ndash The Planning Service has ruled there will not be a public inquiry into one of the biggest private housing developments ever proposed for Down District.Public scrutiny of an ambitious poundm plan to build over  new homes and a marina at the Gocean area in Killyleagh had been widely expected, but planning officials have decided against an inquiry.They confirmed on Monday afternoon that the application by Ravenblack Developments, which was being dealt with by senior planners in Belfast, has been passed back to planners in Downpatrick. They will now re-examine the proposal before making their views known to local councillors.It has been widely expected the inquiry would have taken place next year, but the fact that it has not been ordered could result in construction work on the project beginning sooner than expected, provided planning permission is granted.DOWNPATRICK ndash A group of residents in Downpatrick are seeking urgent talks over a proposal to build  new homes in the town.The Ardglass Road residents are hoping to meet senior planning officials and Roads Service engineers to discuss what will be Downpatrickrsquos largest building project for several years.They say while they have no objections to the proposal to build several hundred new homes, they do have concerns about the increase in the amount of traffic the development will generate.Councillor Mrs Anne Trainor said the existing roads infrastructure is already struggling to cope with the demands being placed on it and will not be able to cope with more traffic.She admits while the construction of the homes will be good news for the local economy, shops, schools and churches, it is important the existing roads network is upgraded.Details of the scheme to build the new homes on land formerly owned by the Down Lisburn Trust was made public last week and local residents has been given two weeks to register any opinions.The new homes are to be built by the Ballygowan firm of Micwall Developments and the scheme is due to receive its public launch in August or September.BALLYCULTER ndash Organic chickens bred at a Ballyculter farm could soon be featuring on supermarket shelves across the Province.The new initiative, which is being spearheaded by organic farmer Dr John Orr, is being backed by the Crossgar firm of Bells Poultry, which hopes to take its first delivery of free-range chickens later this week.By Friday the birds will be on sale in butcherrsquos shops in Belfast and Dublin andsuccessful, the move to breed organic chickens locally could knock the stuffing out of European competition.The plan was hatched several months ago and Mr Adrian Gunn the agricultural manager with the Crossgar firm, believes the market is ready for an increase in the number of organic chickens.He said with an increasing number of consumers turning to organic products, the time is right to move in this direction and supply them with organic poultry products.STRANGFORD ndash Local school children braved the April showers on Monday to take part in a historic event.Armed with wellington boots and spades, pupils and teachers from St Josephrsquos Primary School in Strangford joined members of the Woodland Trust at Compass Hill outside Strangford, to plant the first trees of the new millennium woodland.Monday was the first stage of the project which saw the children helping to plant a new woodland which has been envisaged for them when they grow up.A new footpath is being built which leads to the Lough shore with breathtaking views from Compass Hill and the Tea House.The woodland and hedges which are being planted have been specially chosen to encourage bird and insect populations and work is currently underway to clean and restore the old Japanese pond.A number of relaxation areas have also been pinpointed for the positioning of seats, along with wooden sculptures which pupils at the local schools helped design.The sculptures of woodland animals have poems, which were written by the children, beautully carved below them and will be there for further generations to admire.CASTLWELLAN ndash Castlewellanrsquos famous May Day horse fair, which has been a feature of le in the market town for generations, has fallen victim to the foot and mouth crisis.Down Council had this week ruled that the traditional horse fair, which attracts hundreds of people of Castlewellan, cannot go-ahead on May .The decisions to cancel the event was taken at a special meeting in Downpatrick on Monday night, but politicians have agreed to allow the fair to proceed on May .They argue it would be unwise to allow people from rural areas to meet in large numbers in Castlewellan for the annual May Day fair and to bring horses in to Castlewellan.But the politicians have given a guarantee they will continue to monitor the current situation and have agreed thatcircumstances change and new directives are issued by the Department of Agriculture, the horse fair could proceed..prettyPhoto

title: Funnyman Brian compiles humorous stories
story: FOR over  years Brian Johnston has been involved in entertainment, compering concerts and appearing at after dinner s and events for numerous church, charitable and other organisations throughout the province and further afield.Ten years ago Brian, who lives near Temple, published a collection of the stories he has told over the years. That book has been bought by people of all ages and from every walk of le, with many of them finding their way right across the world.The money raised, in excess of pound,, has all been for charity, initially for Marie Curie Cancer Care, and more recently for the Motor Neurone Disease Association.Over the past year or two, Brian has been often asked when he was going to bring out another book, so  months ago at the start of lockdown, he decided that it would be a good time to put pen to paper.The result is lsquoMore Humorous Storiesrsquo, which has just been released. Again, all money raised will to go to the Motor Neurone Disease Association.Brian has always enjoyed entertaining through the guise of other characters, and so many years ago he created the lsquoman huntingrsquo cleaning woman, lsquoDaisy Hardcastlersquo and lsquoWee Billyrsquo, the mischievous schoolboy. So in addition to over  stories, he has included the dialogue that these two have shared with audiences over the years.He feels privileged that the distinguished journalist Alf McCreary has been kind enough to write the foreword for the book, which includes the following words:ldquoHumour is one of the great joys at any time, but following the long period of lockdown and the great suffering caused by the pandemic, we need humour more than ever before. So I congratulate Brian on his inspired efforts and I wish him every success in this new and welcome venture.Brian says the Motor Neurone Disease Association, like so many other charities, has suffered greatly over the past  months, with limited opportunities for fundraising events to take place.ldquoHopefully sales of this little book will help them to continue the tremendous work that they do, he remarked.ldquoThe money they raise is used to provide patient care locally, including the provision of specialist equipment, and also for continued support of research into this terrible disease.Anyone interested in purchasing the book can contact Brian either by email: brianmjohnston@btinternet or by telephoning him on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Grieving mum pays thanks after poetry book launch
story: A BOOK of poems written by the mother of a Killyleagh man who died following an attack outside a Portaferry pub has gone on sale.Jayne Macrae was moved to write poetry after the two men responsible for the manslaughter of her only son Ryan , who died on October  in , were sentenced in January.Jordan Donnelly, , of Ardminnan Road, Portaferry, and Robert Kiernan, , of Princetown Road, Bangor, initially denied murder but later pleaded guilty to manslaughter. They were jailed for eight years and nine years respectively.Over pound has been raised within days of the book, My Le in Rhyme, containing  poems, going on sale last Thursday.All proceeds will go to the charity REVIVE which helps the intensive care unit at Belfastrsquos Royal Victoria Hospital, where Ryan lost his fight for le nine days after suffering brain injuries in the attack.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker encouraged Jayne to write a collection after seeing the response she received after she posted some on social media.He was also instrumental in securing the sponsorship from Downpatrick food producer Dennis Lynn, from Finnebrogue Artisan, to help with the publication costs.Jayne mdash who is also from Killyleagh mdash revealed that it was her sister Lynnrsquos suggestion to channel her depression and grief into writing her feelings down which led her to write the poems.ldquoWhen I began to write, I had no intention to write poetry. I was just putting thoughts down and all the lines came out in rhyme, she said.ldquoFor the two years I was sitting here at home, I was vegetating, which is not like me. I didnrsquot want to do anything. I knew Ryan would have said to me, lsquoCome on Mum, catch yourself onrsquo.Just four months before Ryan died, the mother of two lost her father.One of the poems in the collection is based on the special relationship between them both.ldquoWe understood that Daddy at  had a good innings but the worst of it all was that he and Ryan were such good friends and so close, she explained.ldquoI got Ryan cremated but his ashes lie with his Papa so they are together and friends forever now. Knowing the two of them are together has helped me.ldquoIt was a very traumatic time, but losing a son has been the ultimate and most horric experience I can ever express to anyone, especially by the means in which it was done.ldquoNot only that, one of the boys who did it is now appealing his sentence. He only got four and a half years in prison and the rest out on licence. That shows there is no remorse. If I had done something like that, I would be saying, lsquoRight lock me uprsquo, I would be horried.ldquoThe judicial system in this country is ridiculous. Four years for murdering someone  I know they say it wasnrsquot murder but it was in the end.Another poem, called The Gt, is about a locket of her sonrsquos hair that she kisses every morning to help her get through the day.Jayne was in New Zealand visiting her daughter Rebecca, who had just had her first baby at the time of the attack on her son.ldquoIt took me three days to travel back from New Zealand, knowing my son was seriously ill in hospital. I was literally shaking the whole time, she recalled.ldquoRyanrsquos father, my ex husband Gordon, had flown from England to be with him. We both sat by his bedside when Ryan was stable enough for us to be in the room.ldquoI canrsquot commend the ICU team of doctors and nurses enough who worked with my son. They were amazing but, unfortunately, Ryanrsquos brain injury was too severe.Jayne, who is working on a second book of poems, says of her son: ldquoRyan was actually very shy but once you got to know him, he was always joking around and had a big smile on his face. You would never see him without a guitar and loved to write music and lyrics.She thanked Cllr Walker and Mr Lynn for helping to get the bookpublished and is full of praise for the Killyleagh community.ldquoThe people of Killyleagh have absolutely amazing. They are truly a wonderful people, she said.ldquoThe support they have given me was unbelievable, even today they would still ask me how Irsquom getting on, can they help  When something bad happens, they really rally round big time. Ryanrsquos friends in Portaferry where he lived have also been so supportive and I thank them all.Cllr Walker said: ldquoI would like to thank the bookrsquos sponsor, Dennis Lynn and Finnebrogue Artisan, for without his help we wouldnrsquot been able to publish the book.ldquoI would like to pay tribute to Jayne for she has penned so many poignant poems and itrsquos an excellent collection. I would encourage people to buy the book as itrsquos for a worthy cause.My Le in Rhyme costs pound and can be bought at the Spar Filling Station, Barrettrsquos and local chemist, Gabbies, in Killyleagh and in McCannrsquos General Store in Killinchy..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle rocker to play live gig
story: CORMAC Neeson, the lead singer of local band The Answer, will perform this in a live streamed concert from Portaferryrsquos Portico venue.Itrsquos a welcometo concert performances for the musician who, like many others, has not been able to play in front of a live audience due to the pandemic.He will be performing as a solo artist alongside his good friend, Donal Scullion, and he promises a lively mixture of songs from his  debut solo country album, White Feather, and hits from The Answer.ldquoI will be stepping up with my acoustic guitar and stamp box while Donal will be rolling in with the very many instruments he plays, the Newcastle man told the Recorder about this Saturdayrsquos gig, which starts at .pm.ldquoIt will be more than a one man and his guitar show and itrsquos a chance for me to reinterpret some of the tracks from White Feather and a few of The Answer tracks and hopefully present them in an interesting and engaging way.ldquoThere will be a bunch of new songs as well as one of the benefits of lockdown is having the time to sit down and write.It will be an intimate look at the artist as during the interval, he will be interviewed about his work with the audience being able to submit advance questions.Cormac says hersquos really looking forward as he has spent the last year performing on his own.Hersquos been busy playing every week online with Co Down musician Matt McGinn and friends on the Cocoons live , often including musicians from the Irish Republic, England and friends from Nashville. Itrsquos based on the ldquosongwriters in the round concept where each musician plays before introducing to the other.ldquoIrsquove played nearly  weeks every weekend on the Cocoons  with Matt. Itrsquos been a great outlet for the need in me to play and perform, but aside from that there was a bunch of other gigs.ldquoAt the beginning of lockdown last March, there was a real flourish of online gigs along with a lot of fund-raising gigs. Therersquos been good causes behind the online gigs and Cocoon does a dferent charity every week. Last weekend we raised just over pound, for Mencap NI.ldquoYoursquove got to deal with whatrsquos in front of you as a musician. While I wouldnrsquot trade the online  for doing it for real, it has been a priceless  to continue to stay sharp and keep writing songs and not forgetting about that adrenalin rush you get when you are performing.Cormac says Cocoons has built up a great ldquocommunity of musicians and online audience of fans.ldquoTherersquos often two brand new artists being introduced each week and they can be from anywhere in the world, he explained. ldquoOnly last Saturday we had Brian Kennedy play in Dublin, then it came to me in Belfast and we went to LA for Ricky Warwick, and then back to Belfast for  year-old Roisin McHugh.Like many other musicians, Cormac had a busy year planned for  with two dferent tours and multiple summer festivals lined up.He was about to release a single from White Feather, his album which charted at number  in the UK national Country Rock album charts.ldquoI had to cancel two full tours, and who knows what  would have been in the pipeline, so quite a bit of work was lost, said Cormac.ldquoLast March I was still rehearsing for my first solo tour around UK and Ireland. I had another tour planned for last autumn, which would have also taken me around Europe as well but that fell by the wayside due to Covid.ldquoI donrsquot give it too much thought now as it happened. To be honest, Irsquove been pretty lucky as therersquos people whorsquove lost a lot more than me. Irsquove had plenty to do online and Irsquove done session work online. I also work with a college in Dublin and Irsquove doing a lot of vocal coaching on my Facebook page.The father of six year-old son Dabhoacuteg and two year-old Conall, Cormac has enjoyed his time at home as a ldquomassive positive, although he admits: ldquoIrsquom looking forward to getting a weekend without the kids.Cormac has promises that therersquos some good things ahead for The Answer fans.ldquoOnce things get back to normal, I will be touring solo again but Irsquove been in regular contact with the boys from The Answer about our next steps so itrsquos all positive.ldquoBut I will also release a few new singles myself as therersquos a few whispers of festivals being held this summer.The Portico concert is being presented by partnership with Portico and Ards and North Down Borough Council.Tickets cost pound per device and are on sale now at: https:www.porticoards event cormac-neeson-live-stream.Cormacrsquos Vocal Coaching and Cocoons live music  can be found on Facebook..prettyPhoto

title: Pharma chief in vaccine roll out
story: A DOWNPATRICK man is leading the roll-out of  million doses of a new Covid- vaccine.Roger Connor is the president of GSKGlobal Vaccines and his company should start making the Novavax vaccine at its Barnard Castle facility in the north east of England next month.While the vaccine is still to be approved, GSK is already working with Novavax in the anticipation of being part of the massive manufacture.Mr Connor is a former pupil of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and a graduate of Queenrsquos University Belfast.He retains close links locally through his family and former school friends and holidays in Strangford each year.He spoke of how GSK has been involved over the last year in the fight against Covid-.ldquoAs the worldrsquos biggest vaccines manufacturer, in GSK we make hundreds of millions of doses in a typical year, he told BBC Five Live.ldquoCovid- is going to require billions. This pandemic is on such a scale itrsquos going to need multiple vaccines so we have always been talking to many dferent players around the world to try and create what we think of as a global response.Mr Connor explained that vaccines, such as Pfizer and AstraZeneca, have been rolled out so quickly because manufacturers are making their products before they are given formal approval.ldquoIf it doesnrsquot succeed then, itrsquos thrown away but it saves you vital weeks, days, monthsyou manufacture at risk in a pandemic situation, he said.ldquoWe wouldnrsquot always do that for a vaccine coming through for other conditions but for this therersquos no choice.He said GSK wants to make sure all countries have access to vaccines.ldquoWe have to make sure that the developing world is not left behind here, he said.ldquoWe were not ready globally for this pandemic. We need to be better prepared for the next so collaboration across governments, including companies, and working on where the gaps were, plugging the gaps, will be important. Itrsquos not lsquowill this happen again rsquo - this will happen again, itrsquos just going to be when.Mr Connor said that while his challenging job got even more challenging over the last year, it had ldquobeen nothing but a privilege to lead the big pharma firm.ldquoTherersquos been a lot of questions and a few extra hours here and there but who wouldnrsquot love this job whenever yoursquore working at a place which is going to make a dference to so many lives .prettyPhoto

title: Popular Castlewellan businessman retires after 25 years
story: AFTER nearly  years of running one of Castlewellanrsquos most popular shops, owner Joe Rogan has now retired as the helpful and ever friendly owner of JRrsquos store.Founded with his we Maria in , Joe and his staff turned the shop at  Main Street into an integral part of le in the town.Whether it was to post a card or parcel, as JRrsquos also incorporated the townrsquos post office, or to buy anything from a bottle of milk to a three-piece suite or to take the children to the shoprsquos annual Santa Claus visit, popping into JRrsquos was a must.The  year-old is delighted to have found an owner like local woman Lisa McKeown to take forward the now Todayrsquos Local branded store into the future.However, Joe and his family are proud that their business became part of Castlewellanrsquos living history.ldquoBecause we were right in the centre of the town, we became a bit of a focal point and known for playing music out of the shop, said Joe.ldquoIt was always a good, friendly shop. That was the whole point of it. Everybody got spoken to, everybody was made to feel welcome, whether you bought anything or not. Irsquove always said to the staff to make sure that they said hello to everybody who came over the door.ldquoThe opportunity arose to sell the property and the business and it call came up at the right time. With everything that is going on at the minute, I just thought, lsquoLe is too shortrsquo and I want to enjoy what bit of le I have left when I can with my we Maria.A consummate salesman, Joe said the early days were fun ones.ldquoWhen we first started out at  Main Street, it was a discount store, what we would have called a swag shop in the old days as we were selling things around a pound and were known as JRrsquos Discount Store, he recalled.ldquoWe opened up on December  in , it was on a Tuesday and it snowed. I would go to the wholesalers on Tuesday and Thursday nights and on Sunday morning, get stock and put it on the shelf and sell it and do it all over again. It was great. The people of Castlewellan was so good that it was always a pleasure to go into work.ldquoThen In , we moved into the big shop at  Main Street and started todo a bit of bedroom and living room furniture and garden furniture.ldquoWe became known as JRrsquos of Castlewellan in  and on February , . we took over the main post office and it became part of JRrsquos. Last February, just before lockdown, we became part of the Todayrsquos Local group so everything has worked out so well.ldquoI wish Lisa all the very best for the future and Irsquom delighted to say that all the staff are staying on. Lisa has great ideas and I know she will drive on the business and take it to the next level.It was Joe mainly working in the business at the start but he eventually employed nine staff with several of them working there nearly as long as he had.He explained sales was always in his blood.ldquoIrsquove been in sales for over  years. Even though I started off as a mechanic, my first real job was as a door to door salesman for a mail order business, he said.ldquoI always wanted to be put on my own and have my own place. My father was a shoe repairer and he had a wee business in Drumaness. I think I got the love of being my own boss from him.As Joersquos shop expanded, so did his family with children coming along, Alanna, a  year-old physiotherapist, Ceara, a  year-old classroom assistant and  year-old Connor, who is a first year university student ndash all of whom helped out in the shop with Ceara still working at the weekends.Connor and his father toasted the recent sale of the business on the day with a dram of Proper Twelve Irish Whiskey. Joersquos mother, Mrs Rosaleen Rogan ndash who will celebrate her th birthday on May  ndash has been a stalwart supporter of her son down the years and was there when Joe handed over the keys to the new owner.Joe admitted he found that last year one of the toughest he had been through during the last quarter century.ldquoIt was tough, the shop was opened throughout the pandemic and I continued to work between - hours each week, he said.ldquoWhile we had other tough years, lockdown was definitely dferent. We had the extra stress of wondering whether we could catch the virus and bring it home. In the first lockdown, you were coming home and straight into the shower, washing your clothes every night and such.ldquoYou always had that wee bit of fear at the back of your mind. The biggest thing for me was not being able to shake peoplersquos hands anymore. I found that really hard. I normally would always be shaking hands, and even giving hugs, but that changed and everyone had to keep the two metres part.ldquoI found it all stressful but it also helped to pave in the road to retiring.Once international travel s to normal, Joe and his we hope toto the Amalfi Coast off Italy and to visit family in Florida and he plans to work on his golf handicap..prettyPhoto

title: Pupils join forces to create Then and Now storyboarding
story: THE lsquoThen and Nowrsquo mural initiative at the former Downe Hospital site which has caught the eye is being led by the creative minds of local P pupils.Led by Down Community Arts, Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Downpatrick District Electoral Area Forum, the initiative challenged pupils from St Colmcillersquos, St Brigidrsquos, Our Lady and St Patrick and Downpatrick primary schools to provide creative ideas for artist Eoin McGinn to produce a community mural storyboarding the rich history of Downpatrick.Working with the childrenrsquos ideas Eoin created the mural in his unique style to depict aspects of Downpatrickrsquos history from St Patrick to John De Courcy right through to the modern day Downpatrick racecourse.The initiative has proven to be an example of how pulling together can bring about great change locally and it has really made a dference to the area and provided an opportunity for children to be involved in creating community pride.Down Community Arts project manager Philip Campbell said the initiative would not have been possible without the support of its funders.He said they included the Arts Council, local council, Clanmil Housing Association, Phoenix Natural Gas and the County Down Rural Community Network.Philip added: ldquoWithout doubt however, our biggest thanks go to the children involved and Eoinwho managed to put together an inspiring piece of work..prettyPhoto

title: Ryan puts pen to paper for Ballymacash outfit
story: BALLYNAHINCH goalkeeper Ryan Walsh has completed a move to Mid-Ulster League outfit Ballymacash Rangers.The former Ballynahinch Olympic shot-stopper enjoyed  years of success at his hometown club including six promotions and winning the Border Cup.Walsh helped take his Ballynahinch side all the way to the Amateur Premier League. However, the  year-old custodian has now decided to move on to join the new project at Lisburn-based Ballymacash.ldquoAfter listening to the club itself, the expectations and future planning is very exciting, he said. I feel the challenge is ambitious, and I feel like I want to be apart of it.ldquoThe signings the manager has brought in are unbelievable. Players such as Michael Moore with the odd age and experience and talented players like Nigel Prentice, Josh Cahoon and Scott Dornan to name a few. I just feel asa new challenge will be good for myself.Walsh thanked his former team as he looked forward to new beginnings.ldquoOlympic are my boyhood club and I wish the boys all the best for the season ahead. There is no doubt Irsquoll be back to support them on my free weekends, he remarked.ldquoI want to thank Olympic for accepting me to move on and signing the transfer. Yes, I took a bit of stick for it, but itrsquos part and parcel of le.Walsh has been a target for Ballymacash manager Lee Forsythe for a considerable amount of time, with Forsythe highlighting what Walsh will bring to his squad.ldquoIn my opinion, Ryan has been the best goalkeeper in the amateur league over the past number of years and I believe he will be worth an extra  points over the course of a season for us, Forsythe said.ldquoBallynahinch Olympic is a really well run club, the players are hard to get away from there, but what we are building here excited Ryan.Ballymacash recently received a pound million pound investment, with a state-of-the-art pitch and clubhouse among the welcome additions.Forsythe also mentioned the importance of the experience Walsh brings to the team, noting he is part of a long term plan.ldquoRyan will also be a massive benefit to help with the development of our  year-old goalkeeper Rhys Lawson who we also rate highly.ldquoRyan has only ever been at two other clubs, so he is a loyal boy and is here to stay. We want to utilise him as a mentor to the next generation coming through.Walsh has starred in two Border Cup finals, putting in the man of the match performance in his teamrsquos agonising penalty shootout loss to Crumlin Star in . He would not rest on his laurels for long, however, as the claret and blue side won the trophy a year later.ldquoThere has been quite a few highs whilst at Olympic said Walsh. ldquoStarting with the acceptance to get into amateur league football, winning and gaining promotion for several leagues with winning Division A being one of the best feelings.ldquoGaining Premier Division status for a small club like Olympic was huge, alongside back-to-back Border Cup finals was great.ldquoObviously, losing to Star in the first final on penalties wasnrsquot nice to take, but beating Rathfriland in the final tops it.Walsh has now set his sights on a potential season ahead, with his own long term plans in mind for his new club.ldquoMy aims for the long term is hoping to be able to push Ballymacash to become a championship side. Making the move to Ballymacash will be great exposure for myself too and the messages Irsquove received from players and some management from other amateur league clubs have been respectful.He continued: ldquoThe support I have received from players, committee and fans of the Ballymacash has blown me away. I want to thank Lee and Ballymacash for giving me this great opportunity. Irsquom very excited and hope we can bring silverware to the club this season..prettyPhoto

title: Sizzling at St Patrick’s
story: AFTER an absence of over three months local golfers ed to the fairways last Thursday.The resumption after the lockdown brought welcome activity at all local clubs.At St Patrickrsquos in Downpatrick the high scoring at the weekend indicated that the shutdown had not affected standards.Mark Jackson won Fridayrsquos sweep competition on a count back from Eamon Fitzsimons after both players ed  points. Daniel Teggart was third with  points.Barry Fitzsimons won the gross category with a  and the gold category went to Leo Rooney with  points.David Higgins claimed Saturdayrsquos top spot with  points after a close and entertaining battle with Caolain Boyd who finished just a point behind. Gareth Reilly and Ed Baggley Sr placed third and fourth respectively with  points.Declan Curran and Mark McGrath claimed fth and sixth positions respectively with  points andMichael Gracey found himself in the top seven after finishing on  points.On Sunday Thomas OrsquoDwyer just got the better of Mark Murphy to finish in first place after both scored  points.For the second day in a row Ed Baggley Sr put in another notable display, this time to finish third on  points ahead of Colm Holland and Paul Rice, who also had  points, while Barry Toner was sixth with  points.The winner of the gold category for the weekends was the evergreen Gerry McConvey with  points..prettyPhoto

title: Soccer action to make comeback
story: LOCAL soccer clubs are in preparation after the resumption of training was given the green light.The Stormont Executive announced a plannedto training from April .Celtic Bhoys FC, Downpatrick and Killough FC are among the local clubs which have welcomed the news with open arms following a frustrating last few months.Celtic Bhoys FC have been working hard behind the scenes to prepare for training to take place at their newly built Ballyhornan facility.Club chairman Patrick Moore said: ldquoWe are really excited to be able to start afresh this season and make the most of our new state of the art G pitch and clubroom at Ballyhornan.ldquoWe will aim to maximise this as a community hub for local people and families throughout the coming year and we firmly believe this will provide a  for the club to grow and prosper in the post Covid- world.He continued: ldquoThere is no doubt that this has been an extremely dficult year for so many, particular those who have lost loved ones as a result of the pandemic.ldquoThe club is excited to have the opportunity to once again provide sporting and social activities to young and old in the local community. That is something that will be particularly important to peoplesrsquo health and wellbeing.Moore said Celtic Bhoys have big plans for their future and are hopeful that they can be in an even better position than they once were.ldquoWe want our community to to come back even stronger than it was before the pandemic. Sport will play a vital role in this regard and with that in mind we plan to create as many teams as possible in all age sections from first kickers right up to over s.Killough FC are also looking ahead to resume training after a frustrating wait to play the Bobby Dalzell Cup final against Ballynahinch Olympic.Manager Conor Doyle spoke about the Executiversquos announcement, stating: ldquoTo the club itrsquos massive. We were well prepared in the summer to get going in August and it was so start-stop.ldquoAfter being told we can train in bigger numbers and for us to get a few friendlies, then for us just to be stripped of it was very disheartening. Not only for the players, but for the management and the committee as they were working extremely hard to cover all of the guidelines so the boys could get a friendly and train.He added: ldquoThe most disheartening thing to happen in our football due to Covid- was being unable to play the cup final.ldquoEveryone has their own opinion on when or how it should have been played long ago, but I am sure the Newcastle League did everything the could to play it in the safest environment possible.He added: ldquoAto training means a massive lt to not only our club, but for the village as well. Everyone in the village supports the club massively, so for them being able to go to The Mill Field on a Saturday and watch the boysrsquo means a great deal.ldquoThe local young talent in the village is amazing at the minute and our ultimate goal is to make Killough a force again.The news will no doubt be a much needed boost to all local soccer clubs, signying a big step in the right direction..prettyPhoto

title: Top marks for Emma after she secures spot at Oxford University
story: A STUDENT from Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has gained a place on the Oxford University UNIQ programme.Emma Keown is a Year  student who applied for and achieved the prestigious placement during lockdown.She will be taking part in the digital version of the universityrsquos residential summer school. The programme is very competitive and exists to encourage highly able students to consider applying to Oxford.It is hoped that the placement will help Emma decide whether she will want to apply to Oxford to study medicine after her A-Levels.Shimna principal Kevin Lambe congratulated Emma on her achievement.He said: ldquoWe are particularly proud of Emmarsquos achievement, which she has earned for herself during lockdown. Emma is a wonderful student who also makes an outstanding contribution to the Integrated ethos of our school.Mr Lambe also said how much he appreciated the commitment of his students for their working during the recent lockdown and his teaching staff in supporting them.ldquoI also want to pay tribute to the outstanding efforts of our Year  students in completing their UCAS applications, their success rate in receiving offers from the universities of their choice, and also the efforts of Year  students in taking advantage of placements, of summer schools and virtual work experience.Mr Lambe added: ldquoI must also pay tribute to our careers advisor, Alicia Rooney, who keeps ourstudents abreast of every opportunity..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. title: emergency talks to take place following violent unrest in northern ireland
story: Missiles thrown at police during Larne protest   LIVE UPDATES: NI Street Violence - Six baton rounds fired at rioters by PSNI - Brandon Lewis flies in for emergency talks over rioting - Bus drivers are now striking in the centre of Belfast after Wednesday nights attackNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsEmergency talks to take place following violent unrest in Northern IrelandEmergency talks are set to take place in Northern Ireland following a week of violent attacks on police.By Rebecca Black, Cate McCurry and David Young, PAThursday, th April , : pmUpdated Thursday, th April , : pm  "       "  In the latest scenes, which took place in west Belfast on Wednesday, a bus was hijacked and set alight, petrol bombs, masonry and fireworks were thrown at officers and a peace wall gate was lit up in flames.A press photographer was also attacked.Justice Minister Naomi Long has said it is a “miracle that no-one was killed”. Police quelled crowds of  people on either side of the peace line and deployed six AEPs, a type of plastic bullet, as well as arresting two men, aged  and , on suspicion of riotous behaviour.Secretary of State Brandon Lewis was due to arrive in Northern Ireland later to hold emergency talks with the main political parties, as well as faith and community leaders.Mr Lewis will meet with First Minister Arlene Foster, from the DUP, and deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill, from Sinn Fein, on Thursday afternoon, the PA news agency understands.He has urged all communities to work together to end the violence, saying the determination to move on from the Troubles could not be “crushed by a small minority”.There have been six consecutive nights of violence across Northern Ireland.Sir Keir Starmer has urged Boris Johnson to “step up” and convene all-party talks, as he noted unionist concerns that the Prime Minister’s Brexit promises were not being kept.Earlier, ministers in the Stormont Executive condemned the violence and Stormont MLAs unanimously passed a motion calling for an end to the disorder.In a joint statement, the five-party Executive said: “While our political positions are very dferent on many issues, we are all united in our support for law and order and we collectively state our support for policing and for the police officers who have been putting themselves in harm’s way to protect others.“We, and our departments, will continue to work together to maximise the support we can give to communities and the PSNI to prevent further violence and unrest.”More than  PSNI officers have been injured since the violence started last week.The Stormont Assembly was recalled from Easter recess for an emergency sitting following a motion put forward by Ms Long calling for MLAs to unequivocally condemn those involved and support the rule of law.Speaking during the Assembly debate, DUP leader Mrs Foster said the scenes witnessed were “totally unacceptable”.The First Minister said the injuries to police officers, harm to Northern Ireland’s image and people’s property had taken the region backwards.She said that the future required political leadership.The PSNI has said it intends to review footage to identy those involved in violence.Ms O’Neill said the violence was dangerous and unacceptable.She said illegal loyalist paramilitaries and criminal elements were influencing young people and orchestrating the violence.“They are holding back their own people and they are holding back their own community,” she said.But Assistant Chief Constable Jonathan Roberts later said during a press conference that he could not confirm whether paramilitary groups were involved in recent riots.“I can’t confirm the involvement of paramilitaries but the orchestration of last night’s disorder and the previous nights is the subject of investigation,” he said during a press conference at PSNI headquarters in Belfast.“The scale of the disorder last night was at a scale that we have not seen in recent years in Belfast or further afield.“The fact that it was sectarian violence involving large groups on both sides is not something we have seen in recent years. We believe there was a level of pre-planning.”An estimated  people gathered on either side on the Lanark Way peace wall gates from pm, which escalated to “signicant disorder”.The violence is unfolding at a time of increasing rancour in the political sphere amid tensions over Brexit’s Irish Sea trade border and the fallout from the police’s handling of a mass republican funeral that took place during pandemic restrictions last year.As rioting has flared across Northern Ireland, all four main unionist parties continue to call for PSNI Chief Constable Simon Byrne to quit over how his service dealt with the funeral of former IRA leader Bobby Storey.Unionists are furious at a decision by prosecutors not to take action against  Sinn Fein politicians, including Ms O’Neill, for attending the funeral – a decision partly related to the fact that police had engaged with organisers before the event that drew , people on to the streets.Mr Byrne has vowed not to resign and has signalled a desire to engage with people who have concerns about policing in the region.Wednesday’s scenes of violence flooded social media and prompted UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson to appeal for calm.He tweeted: “I am deeply concerned by the scenes of violence in Northern Ireland, especially attacks on PSNI who are protecting the public and businesses, attacks on a bus driver and the assault of a journalist.“The way to resolve dferences is through dialogue, not violence or criminality.”---A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt has been an extraordinary  months which have changed our lives in terms of health, financial well-being and simple social contact with family and friends.And it has been a year in which everyone became interested in the daily numbers of the pandemic. One year on, what does the data tell us about how Covid- has hit the Vale of Glamorgan Cases and deathsSince the early days of the pandemic, we have been provided with regular updates on the number of new positive cases and, sadly, reported deaths.Inthe Vale of Glamorgan, , people had tested positivefor Covid- by the morning of March , Public Health England data shows.According to the Office for National Statistics,  deaths involving the viruswere provisionally registeredin the areaup to March .Of those,  occurred in hospitals, while there were  deaths in care homes and  at private homes.A further six deaths occurred in hospices, other community establishments or where.It means deaths which happened outside hospital settings accounted for % of the overall toll.Health experts have repeatedly said "excess deaths" ndash the number of deaths above the annual expected numberndashare a better measure of the overall impact of the coronavirus pandemic than simply looking at mortality directly linked to Covid-.ONS figures on this show that , people died of all causes inthe Vale of Glamorgan between March  and February ndash the latest available data.That was % above the , deaths which occurred over the same period a year earlier.The labour marketAs well as being the biggest health crisis in decades, the coronavirus pandemic has also brought rapid change to the UKs jobs market.Unemployment rates have surged along with a rise in job uncertainty, and many more people are seeking support from unemployment benefits.     One of the defining elements of the Governments response to the spread of Covid- was the launch of emergency income support schemes to protect jobs.Back in March last year, Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, or "furlough" scheme, to help firms struggling with the impact of the virus.By the end of May, just two months later, businesses had already put around , employments on furlough in the Vale of Glamorgan.At the same time, people in the area had made roughly , claims made under the separate Self-Employment Income Support Scheme.MORE NEWS:In January, , jobs were on furlough in the Vale of Glamorgan, with , reliant on the SEISS scheme.ONS figures show that in early March last year, ,people in the Vale of Glamorgan were claiming out-of-work benefits.By mid-January, that figure had risen nearly double to ,.The figures include those aged  to  on Jobseekerrsquos Allowance and some Universal Credit claimants, who are unemployed and seeking work or employed but with low earnings.The ONS has regularly cautioned that changes to Universal Credit in response to the virus mean more people can get the benefits while still being employed, which mean the figures cant be used to measure unemployment on a local basis.It also said a small number of people who can claim both JSA and UC could be counted twice.What about house prices The property market has also felt the impact of the pandemic, withthe average UK house price rising to a record pound, at the end of last year.The ONS saidGovernment support schemes, particularly the stamp duty holiday, may be a factor behind the national rise.But not everywhere saw a growth in house prices, however.Inthe Vale of Glamorgan, the average cost of a property was pound, in February, just before the Covid- crisis hit, according toLand Registry figures.By December, that had fallen to pound,ndasha decrease of less than .%.VaccinationsAfter an extremely dficult year for many of us, the vaccine rollout is providing a glimmer of hope for a le not bound by restrictions.Public Health Wales data shows , people in the Vale of Glamorgan and Cardf had received their first dose of a Covid- vaccine
